name: Mojito
biography: Is it time to race already?? **Yawn** Sorry I’m so tired, I spent last night out on the town to shellebrate my debut in the Tour de Turtles! My name is Mojito but I’m commonly known as Moji around these waters. I don’t know if you’ve noticed yet but my shell happens to be quite a work of art. I’m not about to nest on just any beach with this masterpiece on my carapace! Unfortunately, instead of just admiring me, some humans want to take my gorgeous shell and make it into art of their own, like jewelry. While I’m all for a good statement necklace, I don’t think hurting sea turtles is a very nice statement, do you? And what am I supposed to do without my shell, be a naked turtle?! I sure hope your answer is no and you join me and my friends at the Sea Turtle Conservancy in raising a glass and spreading the word about the illegal shell trade. Remember, you can look but you can’t touch!
description: Mojito (aka Moji) is an adult hawksbill sea turtle released on July 16, 2017 with a satellite transmitter. She was encountered nesting on July 16 on Lovers Beach, Nevis. She measured 75.8 cm curved carapace (shell) length and 72.3 cm curved carapace width. Mojito took part in the 2017 Tour de Turtles.

name: Caroline
project_name: Tracking Loggerheads from the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: Sweet Carolina, bah bah bah! Yup. That’s me. I’m Caroline! My dear friends at Carolina Skiff have sponsored me to educate you guys about the threats we sea turtles face when it comes to commercial trawl fisheries.  I wanna tell y’all a quick story. It was a beautiful day, sunny skies and crystal clear waters. I was just swimming around minding my own business when BAM. I got picked up in this really big weird looking net. In this net were lots of shrimp, and some other of my ocean friends like sharks and rays. We were all so scared and we didn’t know what to do! The shark told me we were stuck in a trawl net, and there should be a trap door called a Turtle Excluder Device (TED) somewhere to help us escape. Luckily, he was right and we made it out safe and sound. Not the shrimp though, oh those poor shrimps! I later found out that these trawl nets are pulled by boats to catch a specific thing, but it ends up catching all kinds of other creatures, like sea turtles, too! Please cheer me on in this race to help raise awareness about this threat. You could potentially be saving some of my turtle buddies!
description: An adult female loggerhead sea turtle to be released with a satellite transmitter on July 30, 2017 from the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. She measured 89.0 cm curved carapace (shell) length and 84.2 cm curved carapace width. Caroline is taking part in the 2017 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, Carolina Skiff.

name: Bortie
project_name: Tracking Turtles from Florida's Gulf Coast
biography: Hi guys! My name is Bortie. I’m going to make Eliza Ann proud by bringing home the title of Tour de Turtles winner this year! I am proud to be an Anna Maria Island girl because I’ve had the support of the staff and volunteers at Anna Maria Island Turtle Watch & Shorebird Monitoring for my whole life. The Turtle Watch crew works very hard to make sure the beach is safe for turtles like me to safely come up to nest. One way they do this is by educating beachfront homeowners about artificial lighting. If I crawl up on the beach and see a white, unshielded light, I will have to turn around and try to find another place to nest, which isn’t ideal for me! White lights are just as dangerous for my hatchlings as well – when they hatch from the nest I dug for them and see a white light, they may crawl toward it and end up in a storm drain, a back yard, on the road, or in the mouth of a predator, which is terrifying! The best way to protect us from artificial white lights is to use FWC certified amber LED bulbs, shield your fixtures and lower them when possible. As they say, Sea Turtles Dig the Dark!
description: Bortie is an adult female loggerhead sea turtles released on June 19, 2018 with a satellite transmitter after nesting on Coquina Beach. She measured 87.1 cm in curved carapace (shell) length. Bortie took part in the 2018 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsors, Anna Maria Island Turtle Watch & Bortell's Lounge.

name: Euphorbia
biography: None
description: Euphorbia is an adult female loggerhead sea turtle released on November 13, 2018 from Gumbo Limbo Nature Center’s Sea Turtle Rehabilitation Facility. She was found wounded swimming in the intake canal of the Port Everglades power plant on April 3, 2018. Gumbo Limbo Rehabilitation Facility treated Euphorbia for multiple predator related injuries to her front flippers. After over six months of rehabilitation, Euphorbia has completely recovered from her injuries and is ready to return to the ocean. Euphorbia measured 90.7 cm straight carapace length and weighed 250 lbs upon release! Data © Gumbo Limbo Nature Center.

name: Mr T
biography: None
description: A magnificent adult male loggerhead sea turtle, Mr. T weighs in at just under 200 pounds. Mr. T was rescued offshore of Tavernier in early February.  Mr. T was floating and had a fishing hook with trailing line lodged in his mouth. Mr. T is fully recovered and ready to return to his ocean home just in time for sea turtle mating season in the Florida Keys!  Mr. T will be fitted with a small transmitter and released on May 7, 2019﻿﻿. Data © Mote Marine Laboratory.

name: Spongie
biography: Hiya! My name is Spongie and I was named after one of my favorite snacks in all the sea! Even though I prefer the slow-paced, island lifestyle most of the time, I agreed to participate in this year’s Tour de Turtles to help out my sponsors at the Four Seasons Nevis. They need me to help spread the word about a serious threat to us hawksbills—illegal shell trade. Unfortunately, instead of just admiring me, some humans want to take my gorgeous shell and make it into art of their own, like jewelry, hair accessories or other trinkets. What am I supposed to do without my shell?! I certainly can’t win a race that way! I hope you’ll join me and my friends at the Four Seasons Resort Nevis in spreading the word about the illegal shell trade. Remember, you can look but you can’t touch! Now I’m off to bulk up on some more sponge to prepare for the big race!
description: Spongie is an adult hawksbill sea turtle released on July 20, 2019 with a satellite transmitter after nesting on the beach at Cade's Bay Beach, Nevis.  She measured 82.2 cm curved carapace (shell) length and 80.2 cm curved carapace width. Spongie took part in the 2019 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, the Four Seasons Resort Nevis.

name: Patches
biography: Oh boy, oh boy! I’m so excited to swim in this year’s Tour de Turtles! My friends at Four Seasons Resort in Nevis named me Patches because the pattern on my shell kinda looks like patches! Pretty neat, right?! I’ve had some other hawksbill friends participate in the Tour de Turtles the past 11 years and it totally sounds like my kind of event. Island hopping, hanging out on the beach, swimming with friends…. Count me in! It might seem like all fun and games now, but one of the reasons I was selected was to raise awareness about the dangers of climate change, a major threat to our beautiful beaches. Because of climate change, sea levels are rising, resulting in the disappearance of many nesting beaches. To battle this problem, humans can use energy-saving methods of transportation, plant vegetation along beaches to provide better nesting habitat, and use more solar or wind energy. I plan to swim throughout the Caribbean to let everyone know about climate change, and hopefully make lots of new friends along the way.
description: Patches is an adult hawksbill sea turtle released on July 21, 2019 with a satellite transmitter after nesting on the beach at Cade's Bay Beach, Nevis.  She measured 85.7 cm curved carapace (shell) length and 81.4 cm curved carapace width. Patches is taking part in the 2019 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsored, Four Seasons Resort Nevis.

name: Phyllis
project_name: Tracking Loggerheads from the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: Hello Dears, I am swimming to raise awareness about the threat of beach erosion. The past few decades I’ve noticed my favorite beaches are eroding. This is bad news for me and other sea turtles, because the only place we can lay our eggs is on sandy beaches, so we all need to work together to make sure I can keep nesting on Florida’s beaches well into the future. Sea level rise is also contributing to beach erosion. So there are few ways you can help, such as limiting emissions where you can, biking to work or carpooling ( like back in my day ), and electing leaders who will address climate change. You can also plant native dune vegetation on beaches, promote coastal construction set-back policies and not build structures on the beach. And the easiest way to help, don’t walk on the dunes let the vegetation grow and collect more and more sand.
description: Philanthropy Phyllis (Phyllis) is an adult female loggerhead sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter on July 28, 2019 from the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. She measured 107.3 cm curved carapace (shell) length and 99.1 cm curved carapace width. Phyllisis taking part in the 2019 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, Community Foundation for Brevard.

name: Zabini
biography: None
description: Zabini is an adult loggerhead sea turtle released on June 12th, 2019 from Gumbo Limbo Nature Center’s Rehabilitation Facility. Zabini’s front left flipper had severe damage from a predator attack. Gumbo Limbo’s Rehabilitation Facility surgically reconstructed her flipper and used maggot and leech treatments to aid in healing. After 4 months, Zabini made a full recovery and was released at Walton Rocks Beach, FL. Data © Gumbo Limbo Nature Center.

name: Hope
biography: Hi friends! I’m Hope! With the support of my fans and sponsors at Turtle & Hughes, I have no doubt I will succeed in the Tour de Turtles race and be the “Hope” that my fellow endangered species needs! While I’m swimming in the marathon, my goal is to teach everyone about the threat of light pollution. Lights from beachfront properties, or even street lights, can disorient nesting turtles like me and our hatchlings. You can learn more about light pollution on the Tour de Turtles website and find out how you can help make a difference. It really is easy! If you’re vacationing at the beach, make sure to only stay at properties that have sea turtle friendly light fixtures, and always close your blinds or shades at night! It’s also super important that you don’t use a flashlight or phone if you’re on the beach at night. With the help of my great and knowledgeable sponsors at Turtle & Hughes, we can win this race and teach everyone about going "lights out" for sea turtles during nesting season!
description: Hope is an adult female leatherback sea turtle that was observed nesting on May 23th 2020 on Jupiter Island, Florida.  She is a rather large Florida leatherback measuring 161.0 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 114.0 cm curved carapace width. Hope is taking part in the 2020 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, Turtle & Hughes, Inc.

name: Tartleby
biography: Hi lovelies! I’m finally ready for my close-up! My sweet friends at tarte cosmetics helped me primp and powder my shell and I can’t wait to show everyone how great I look when I make my Tour de Turtles debut! tarte cosmetics are all-natural and made without harmful chemicals to keep me healthy and ready to shine! It’s just one way I take care of my big beautiful body. I’ve also increased my jellyfish intake this past year to fuel my upcoming migration. Did you know jellies and other marine life can actually become contaminated by chemicals from oil spills and runoff? When these nasty toxins enter the ocean, they never leave! They accumulate in my food and even on the beach, and make my friends and I very sick! Even though everyone will probably be busy admiring my beauty, I hope they also take the time to learn about the importance of water quality during the race. I’m so excited for you to help and cheer me on this journey! Ciao bellas!
description: Tartleby is an adult leatherback sea turtle that was observed nesting on May 23rd, 2020.  She is an average size Florida leatherback measuring 153.5 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 109.0 cm curved carapace width. She is taking part in the 2020 Tour de Turtles and she was named by her sponsor, tarte.

name: Tamarind
biography: Surfs up, dudes! I’m Tamarind! Even though I was born in Florida, I’m quite the world traveler and my name was actually inspired by the delicious tropical fruit that grows in the Bahamas. It was given to me by my amazing sponsors at Atlantis Paradise Island. They’ve been supporting my other leatherback friends for 10 years! I was so excited when I heard it was finally my turn to represent Team Atlantis in this year’s Tour de Turtles race. Hopefully my world experiences will help me win the race! I’ve already visited the coastal waters of many countries. I’m proud to say my travels have been quite sustainable as I’ve been taking my reusable bags, straw and cup with me on my journey and saying “no” to single-use plastic. I definitely don’t want to contribute to the growing problem of plastic debris! I plan to educate as many people as I can about this issue during the Tour de Turtles. Where should I travel next? I’m thinking Canada or Nova Scotia! Catch ya on the flip side!
description: Tamarind is an adult female leatherback sea turtle that was observed nesting on May 21st, 2020 on Jupiter Island, Florida, USA.  She is a small Florida leatherback measuring 147.5 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 97.5 cm curved carapace width. Tamarind is taking part in the 2020 Tour de Turtles and was named by her Sponsor, Atlantis, Paradise Island.

name: Freckles
biography: My name is Freckles and I’m the most lovable leatherback you’ll ever meet! I recently nested on a beautiful beach in South Florida and was just too tickled at the idea of joining the Tour de Turtles. My new human friends asked for my help to raise awareness about a serious threat called beach erosion. Doesn’t that sound frightening?! Almost half of Florida’s nesting beaches are critically eroded. This is bad news for sea turtles like me, because the only place we can lay our eggs is on sandy beaches. Beach re-nourishment is the primary strategy to combat coastal erosion in Florida. While this can help, it must be carried out correctly and under strict guidelines that ensure the "new beach" is compatible for successful nesting. You can also help by planting native dune vegetation on beaches and electing leaders who will address climate change and sea level rise. STC is keeping a close eye on things at home in Florida, so I think it’s about time for me to skedaddle on out of here and spread the word!
description: Freckles is an adult female leatherback sea turtle that was observed nesting on May 22nd 2020 on Jupiter Island, Florida.  She is an average size Florida leatherback measuring 150.5 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 107.0 cm curved carapace width. Freckles is taking part in the 2020 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, Sea Turtle Conservancy.

name: Miss Piggy
project_name: Tracking Loggerheads from the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: Ciao my darlings! In case you failed to notice the star on my green room door, my name is Miss Piggy, and I’m the most fashionable and fabulous loggerhead in the Tour de Turtles! I plan to bring a dash of irresistibility and a great big dollop of attitude to this competition. I have the honor of representing Disney Cruise Line in this year’s marathon. I’m not usually one for running races and exercising but I made an exception for my friends at Disney. They promised there would be cupcakes at the finish line, packaged in eco-friendly plastic-free packaging of course! I plan to win this race the same way I won Kermit’s heart… with my big and beautiful personality! And if all else fails, I’ll just order dessert first!
description: Miss Piggy is an adult female loggerhead sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter on July 21, 2020 from south of the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. She measured 104.5 cm curved carapace (shell) length and 100.0 cm curved carapace width. Miss Piggy had already been pit tagged when we encountered her nesting. Her pit tag had been put on by Mote Marine Lab when she nested on Casey Key on the Gulf Coast of Florida in July, 2012! Miss Piggy is taking part in the 2020 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, Disney Cruise Line.

name: Sandy
project_name: Tracking Loggerheads from the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: What’s up dudes and dudettes?! The name’s Sandy! I was named by my sponsors at Ocean’s Lending who are big lovers of Florida’s sandy beaches. That’s why I’m swimming in this year’s Tour de Turtles to raise awareness about the threat of beach erosion. The past few decades I’ve noticed my favorite beaches are eroding. Totally not tubular! This is especially bad news for me and my sea turtle friends because the only place we can lay our eggs is on sandy beaches. Because sea level rise is contributing to beach erosion, sea turtles need help from you humans so try to limit emissions where you can, elect leaders who will address climate change, plant native dune vegetation on beaches, and whatever you do, don’t walk on my precious dunes!
description: Sandy is an adult female loggerhead sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter on July 21, 2020 from south of the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. She measured 91.1 cm curved carapace (shell) length and 82.3 cm curved carapace width. Sandy is taking part in the 2020 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, Ocean’s Lending.

name: Kermit
project_name: Tracking Loggerheads from the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: Hi folks! I’m Kermit the Turtle, not to be confused with that other green guy… Unlike Kermit the Frog, I’m a female green sea turtle. And let me tell ya, it’s not easy being green! I have to steer clear of buildings with bright lights and watch out for people carrying flashlights on the beach! That’s why I love to come up and lay my eggs near Disney’s Vero Beach Resort. They installed sea turtle friendly lighting on their property and work with Disney’s conservation team to educate guests about how dangerous light pollution can be for sea turtles. With the help of the Disney Team, I will do my very best to win this race and spread the word about the importance of sea turtle friendly lighting! As my namesake, Kermit the frog would say, “time’s fun when you’re having flies!”
description: Kermit is an adult female green sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter on July 21, 2020 from south of the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. She measured 112.4 cm curved carapace (shell) length and 102.9 cm curved carapace width. Kermit is taking part in the 2020 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, Disney Conservation Fund.

name: Koa
project_name: Tracking Loggerheads from the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: Aloha! My name’s Koa, which means brave and fearless in Hawaiian. Even though I naturally prefer the slow-paced, island lifestyle most of the time, I agreed to participate in this year’s Tour de Turtles to help out my sponsors at honu. Life at the beach might seem like a tropical paradise now, but I’m here to raise awareness about the dangers of climate change, a major threat to my favorite beaches. Because of climate change, sea levels are rising, resulting in the disappearance of many nesting beaches. I could really use your help so I can get back to living that aloha life. The folks at honu selected me for the Tour de Turtles because of my fearlessness, so I will do my best to overcome all obstacles for them and bravely combat climate change in the process! Mahalo for all your support!
description: Koa is an adult female loggerhead sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter on July 22, 2020 from the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. She measured 89.1 cm curved carapace (shell) length and 86.4 cm curved carapace width. Koa is taking part in the 2020 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, honu.

name: Gim
project_name: Tracking Loggerheads from the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: Anyong haseyo! That means “hello” in Korean. And my name is Gim, the Korean word for seaweed, which happens to be one of my favorite snacks, along with squid and shellfish. With the help of my friends at gimMe snacks, I am racing in this year’s Tour de Turtles to raise awareness about oil spills. I would hate to get oil on my shell while I’m trying to swim. That stuff just gets all over and won’t come off! It would definitely slow me down, and I’m trying to win this thing! I know it’s not the end of the world a little oil smears on my shell, but it is a big deal if my food has been contaminated. An oil spill could be a real problem if my only food source is covered in it! Plus, I don’t want my little hatchlings swimming through that toxic mess after they finally hatch. I may end up swimming through the Gulf of Mexico, and I know there have been some major oil spills there. I’m counting on my fans and gimMe to help me get through this!
description: Gim is an adult female loggerhead sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter on July 23, 2020 from the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. She measured 93.3 cm curved carapace (shell) length and 90.3 cm curved carapace width. Gim is taking part in the 2020 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, gimMe Snack.

name: Robin
project_name: Tracking Loggerheads from the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: Hey there! My name is Robin and I am one of two adult green turtles participating in the Tour de Turtles. My interests include swimming marathons, accessorizing, and eating a strictly vegetarian diet. I’ve been training hard for my next marathon so I’m spending a lot of time in the water, as most sea turtles do. And you know what I’ve noticed recently? A lot of this water is totally not sanitary! In fact, I heard through the grapevine that humans have been allowing chemicals and waste to run-off in my training area. Even if it isn’t direct pollution, harmful toxins like fertilizer and pesticides are sneakily making their way towards the ocean. Pollutants harm other marine animals and plants too by depleting the water of nutrients and oxygen we all need to survive. I used my connections to hook up with the folks at Wildlife Collections and they’re going to help us put a stop to this madness and raise awareness about this issue. After all, you can’t expect me to swim a race in polluted water… I don’t want to ruin my jewelry!
description: Robin is an adult female green sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter on July 23, <g class="gr_ gr_5 gr-alert gr_gramm gr_inline_cards gr_run_anim Punctuation only-ins replaceWithoutSep" data-gr-id="5" id="5">2020</g> from the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. She measured 100.4 cm curved carapace (shell) length and 98.0 cm curved carapace width. Robin is taking part in the 2020 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, Wildlife Collections.

name: Leia
project_name: Tracking Loggerheads from the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: Hi lovelies, I’m Leia! I’m originally from Florida, but you could say I’m somewhat of a world traveler. I rarely stay in one place for long – there is just too much to do and see out there in the ocean! During my travels, I have seen a lot of amazing things, and some not so amazing things, like commercial trawl fisheries. Trawl fisheries are big boats that drag giant nets behind them, catching all kinds of creatures. What if I got tangled up in one of these fishing nets during the Tour de Turtles?! Then I wouldn’t even be able to finish the race! I’d hate to disappoint my fans and sponsors at Wildlife Collections. To make sure turtles like me don’t get trapped in these dangerous nets, it’s important to only eat sustainably sourced seafood and to support companies and countries that use Turtle Excluder Devices (TEDs) on trawl boats. That way, I can continue living my dream and traveling the globe! I’d really appreciate your help in spreading the word about the dangers of trawl fisheries to your families and friends. If I win this whole thing, I’ll treat everyone to a nice dinner of some sustainable seafood!
description: Leia is an adult female loggerhead sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter on July 22, 2020 from the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. She measured 95.1 cm curved carapace (shell) length and 89.4 cm curved carapace width. Leia is taking part in the 2020 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, Wildlife Collections.

name: Foxy
biography: None
description: Foxy (aka Foxy Charlie) is an adult green sea turtle found on October 1, 2020 in the waters of Islamorada, Florida and entangled in a trap line around a large tumor on its back flipper. She was taken to the Turtle Hospital in Marathon, FL. On October 3, Dr. Brooke removed a tumor that weighed 6 lbs. In early November additional tumors were removed. She was cleared for release and weighed nearly 200 lbs. She was released with a satellite transmitter on Feb 3, 2021.

name: Mandy
project_name: Tracking Loggerheads from the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: Hiya! I’m Mandy! My friends from Shark Reef Aquarium chose me for the Tour de Turtles race to help raise awareness about invasive species predation. I’ve been busy training all summer after I finished nesting in Florida. Since then, I’ve been stretching my flippers and perfecting my dive to take on the other competitors in the Tour de Turtles. Even though I’m super athletic, it’s not easy getting this big, beautiful body up on a beach and laying the perfect nest. And after all of that work, some animals like dogs, raccoons, and coyotes have the NERVE to dig up my nest! You can make sure all of my work doesn’t go to waste by keeping an eye on your pets and picking up trash on the beach so it doesn’t attract raccoons or other animals. We all have to work together to solve this problem, so I’d really appreciate your support in this year’s Tour de Turtles!
description: Mandy is an adult female loggerhead sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter on July 23, <g class="gr_ gr_5 gr-alert gr_gramm gr_inline_cards gr_run_anim Punctuation only-ins replaceWithoutSep" data-gr-id="5" id="5"><g class="gr_ gr_5 gr-alert gr_gramm gr_inline_cards gr_run_anim Punctuation only-ins replaceWithoutSep" data-gr-id="5" id="5">2020</g></g> from the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. She measured 100.4 cm curved carapace (shell) length and 91.6 cm curved carapace width. Mandy is taking part in the 2020 Tour de Turtles and is sponsored by Shark Reef.

name: Maisy
biography: Hi friends! My name is Maisy! I’m not a nesting female like most of the turtles in the marathon, in fact I’m a very special juvenile sea turtle. When I was rescued last July, The Turtle Hospital noticed that I did not look like the other turtles, but had characteristics of both a hawksbill and a green sea turtle.  DNA testing confirmed that I was a rare hawksbill/green sea turtle hybrid!  I was totally not in marathon form when I was first rescued. I was covered in tumors from fibropapillomatosis AND had a severe case of pneumonia!  My friends at the Turtle Hospital helped get me back on my flippers since I wasn’t doing so hot. My treatment included multiple tumor removal surgeries, several bronchoscopy procedures, nebulizer breathing treatments, broad spectrum antibiotics, vitamins, fluids and a healthy diet of seafood and greens. I’ve had almost a year to recover and now I’m tumor-free and ready to head back to the sea!  I’m racing to spread the word about Poor Water Quality because clean water is crucial for sea turtles like me and my non-flippered friends. Make sure to cheer for me and spread the word about my cause!
description: Maisy, a very special sea turtle was rescued off of Summerland Key on 4th of July, 2019 where she was found covered in tumors. Maisy did not look like the other turtles, she had characteristics of both a hawksbill and a green sea turtle. DNA testing confirmed Maisy is a rare hawksbill/green sea turtle that measured 66.5 cm curved carapace (shell) length. Maisy was treated at the Turtle Hospital for fibropapillomatosis and a severe case of pneumonia. When released, Maisy was feisty, tumor free and back to good health! Her transmitter was sponsored by The Turtle Hospital.

name: Rainn
biography: None
description: Rainn (in honor of Rainn Wilson) is an adult loggerhead and was rescued by biologists at Inwater Research Group from the St. Lucie Power Plant on Nov 3, 2020. When Rainn arrived, she was extremely lethargic and had barnacles and marine leeches covering the carapace, indicating the turtle has been lethargic and injured for a while. Under treatment by staff at the Gumbo Limbo Nature Center Sea Turtle Rehabilitation Facility, Rainn started eating and becoming more active within a week of arrival. On January 26, 2021, Rainn was released with a satellite transmitter to monitor her behavior once back in the wild.

name: Richard
biography: None
description: Richard is a female juvenile green sea turtle that was found stranded on Daytona Beach, Florida, in April, 2020. She was very emaciated and was taken to the University of Florida Whitney Laboratory Sea Turtle Hospital. After months of rehabilitation, Richard was doing very well as was released with a satellite tag on November 4, 2020. Richard measured 48 cm SCL (shell length) and is taking part in a study conducted by Mike Arendt with the South Carolina Dept of Natural Resources. She is on the smaller end of the mid-sized juvenile size class that is absent from the coastal size distribution and thus tracking her movements, particularly during the winter months, will provide important information. This is a collaborative effort between SCDNR, UF-Whitney Lab, and STC. Data © South Carolina Dept of Natural Resources.

name: Guava
biography: Hi, I’m Guava! And just like my name suggests, I am sweet and loved by everyone on the islands! Atlantis has been supporting my other leatherback friends in the Tour de Turtles for more than 10 years and now it’s finally my turn!  I am so excited to be representing my Team Atlantis in the race this year, especially because they recently banned single use plastics from their property. This cause is very close to my heart because plastic debris is extremely dangerous to leatherback turtles like me, and all marine-life. Plastic bags and plastic straws have become a real problem lately, but I’m glad I don’t have to worry about running into any of those near the waters around Atlantis… Instead of single-use plastics, they use compostable and paper products, setting a great example for other resorts and hotel properties! Cheer for me and Team Atlantis this year and help us spread the word about the threat of plastic debris and the importance of keeping our beaches and waterways clean!
description: Guava is an adult female leatherback sea turtle encountered nesting on May 24, 2021, on Soropta Beach, Panama. She measured 158.7 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 113.5 cm curved carapace width, and she laid 72 fertile eggs and 48 infertile eggs. Guava is taking part in the 2021 Tour de Turtles, and she was named by her Sponsor, Atlantis Paradise Island.

She took part in the 2011 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsors, Disney's Animal Programs and Disney's Vero Beach Resort.

name: Mayorita

description:
Leatherback

Matapica Beach, Suriname

name: Shakira
project_name: Satellite Tracking of Marine Turtles in the Guianas
biography: A leatherback encountered nesting on May 18, at 11:01 pm. Curved shell length 152 cm, curved shell width 132 cm. She was one of the smaller leatherbacks. She was quite sensitive to the researchers presence and kept making fussy noises.  Researchers were very gentle with her.
description: Matapica Beach, Suriname

name: Beyonce
project_name: Satellite Tracking of Marine Turtles in the Guianas
biography: A leatherback encountered nesting on May 19, at 1:48 am. Curved shell length 145 cm, curved shell width 115 cm. Beyonce had a tough time in the ocean.  Researchers found that her keel ridge had damaged notches and scaring along the shell. There was also a notch missing out of her left front flipper.  It seemed that she may have encountered a fishing net or a boat’s propeller, but either way, based on her injuries, she's a lucky girl to be still swimming around in the ocean.
description: None

name: Alma
project_name: Satellite Tracking of Marine Turtles in the Guianas
biography: A leatherback encountered nesting on May 21 at 9:00 pm. Curved shell length 147 cm. Alma had a long thin scar circling the upper shoulder of the right front flipper. This looked like the result of an injury from a rope from a gill net.
description: None

name: Moruca
project_name: Satellite Tracking of Marine Turtles in the Guianas
biography: A leatherback encountered nesting on May 21 at 10:15 pm. Curved shell length 167 cm, curved shell width 135 cm. She was very broad compared to her length, sort of a chubby girl.  We believe that this may mean that she was just at the start of her nesting cycle, and still had reserves of fat.
description: None

name: Rosa
project_name: Satellite Tracking of Marine Turtles in the Guianas
biography: A leatherback encountered nesting on May 21 at 11:23 pm. Curved shell length 156 cm. Rosa chose to nest between the low and high tide boundaries.  This is not uncommon in leatherbacks, but means that the nest would be flooded as the tide comes in and will reduce the chances of successful hatching. For this reason, the able field team of the Guyana Marine Turtle Conservation Society, after overseeing the tagging of Rosa, dug up and moved her eggs to a new location so that they would have a better chance at successful hatching.
description: None

name: Luria
project_name: Satellite Tracking of Marine Turtles in the Guianas
biography: A green turtle encountered nesting on May 20, but tagged May 21 at 3:43 pm. Luria was waiting for researchers when they arrived on the beach.  It was mid-afternoon, so many small children and adults from the local community of Almond Beach were able to observe her as she was being tagged.  Luria was in almost perfect condition with a clean, really beautiful shell! She did fuss on occasion, clearly preferring to be out at sea rather than under the coconut trees in a tight box. She wasted little time getting to the safety of the ocean, once she was released.
description: None

name: Shellie
project_name: Satellite Tracking of Marine Turtles in the Guianas
biography: A green turtle encountered on May 23 at 12:41 am. Curved shell length 107 cm, curved shell width 102 cm. Researchers needed to tag one more green turtle, but they walked the beach for many hours without a single turtle sighting. Shellie was in the middle of a 'false crawl' when she was found on the beach.  Researchers were never so glad to see a turtle! She was promptly tagged and released soon after. Like Luria, Shellie had a beautiful shell with little to no marks, scratches, barnacles or algae.
description: None

name: Asranti
project_name: Satellite Tracking of Marine Turtles in the Guianas
biography: A leatherback encountered nesting May 17, at 9:53 pm.  Curved shell length 173 cm, curved shell width 140 cm.  Asranti was previously flipper tagged and pit tagged in French Guiana. She was the first leatherback turtle satellite tagged for the 2012 nesting season in Suriname.  Asranti had an unusually large pink spot on the top of her head.
description: None

name: Tyari
project_name: Satellite Tracking of Marine Turtles in the Guianas
biography: A leatherback encountered nesting May 18, at 9:45 pm. Curved shell length 170 cm, curved shell width 128 cm. Tyari was very calm and gave no reaction to researchers on being tagged.  She even allowed researchers to take some photos of her. She was also very focused on her task.  She was very quick to dig her nest, lay her eggs, cover and leave.
description: None

name: Esi
project_name: Satellite Tracking of Marine Turtles in the Guianas
biography: A leatherback encountered nesting on May 19, at 2:15 am. Curved shell length 146 cm, curved shell width 135 cm. Esi must always know where she's going because the pink spot on her head was shaped like an arrow pointing forward. There was mud all over her carapace indicating she went through the mud banck to get to shore. Boy, was she determined to nest! Her left front flipper was missing large sections, but she had no trouble choosing a nest site that was very high on the beach and near alot of drift wood.
description: None

name: Sekanti
project_name: Satellite Tracking of Marine Turtles in the Guianas
biography: A leatherback encountered nesting on May 19, at 1:22 am. Curved shell length 156 cm, curved shell width 120 cm. She was not as gentle with her eggs as some of the other turtles, in fact, she was a bit rough. Researchers found scars on her carapace and right front flippers indicating that she had a bad encounter with an object in the ocean. The pink spot on her head looked alot like a jelly fish and she had an additional pink spot on her nose.

name: Panama Jack
biography: Oh boy, oh boy, oh boy, am I excited to be participating in the 7th annual Tour de Turtles, woo-hoo! I'm Panama Jack, but my friends call me Splashin' PJ because I can barely sit still! I'm an adult female leatherback sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter after nesting on Punta Rincon Beach, Panama on May 25, 2014. I measure 145.0 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 108.0 cm in curved carapace width. I returned and nested again on July 15. I just love swimming and splashing and diving as deep as I can. Racing in the Tour de Turtles is going to be such a hoot! Even though crawling up the beach and laying nearly 100 eggs in Panama was tiring, I've had some time to rest and now have all my energy back! I'm ready to swim as far and fast as I can to help raise awareness for a good cause, and that is to teach all you folks about the dangers of light pollution. You can learn all about my cause on the Tour de Turtles website and find out how you can help make a difference. It really is easy... Make sure to install sea turtle friendly lights on any of your beachfront property and always close the blinds and shades during nesting season. With the help of my great and knowledgeable sponsors at Turtle & Hughes, Inc, we can teach everyone about going "Lights Out" for sea turtles during nesting season! Oh, this is going to be so much fun! Don't forget to cheer me on during my journey, I plan on swimming fast and far!
description: An adult female leatherback sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter from Punta Rincon Beach, Panama on May 25, 2014. She measured 145.0 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 108.0 cm in curved carapace width. Taking part in the 2014 Tour de Turtles. Seen nesting again on July 15.

name: Calypso Blue III
biography: Hello there, or as my friends in my native country of Panama would say it, hola! My name is Calypso Blue III. I'm an adult female leatherback sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter from Soropta Beach, Panama on May 27, 2014. I measure 144.6 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 108.0 cm curved carapace width, and laid 53 fertile eggs and 36 yokeless eggs. Despite the rumors being spread that turtles are a slow species, I'd like to put an end to all that gossip by making my sponsors at Atlantis Resort proud and winning the Tour de Turtles race and setting a new record while I'm at it! Last year, my distant cousin Calypso Blue II won the marathon by swimming 2,836 miles. Not only do I plan on winning, I'm also going to educate people about the dangers of commercial trawl fisheries. I keep trying to tell these fishermen that they've got the wrong gal but their gill nets keep trying to haul me away! Now, I know these guys are just trying to capture shrimp and stuff but after the 150,000 accidental injuries and deaths of my friends, something needs to be done. To show my dedication to this cause, I will be swimming across the ocean to try and put an end to the danger caused by fisheries. The least they could do is make sure to install Turtle Excluder Devices (TEDs) on their nets! Follow me on my journey by taking a look at my marathon migration map. This way, you can see my progress and cheer me on along the way. Wish me luck, although I don't need it. Us leatherbacks almost always win the race.
description: Calypso Blue III is an adult female leatherback sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter from Soropta Beach, Panama on May 27, 2014. She measured 144.6 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 108.0 cm curved carapace width, and laid 53 fertile eggs and 36 yokeless eggs. Calypso Blue III is taking part in the 2014 Tour de Turtles.

name: Estrella
biography: Greetings to everyone out there following the Tour de Turtles! My name is Estrella (Spanish for "star") and I'm a critically endangered hawksbill sea turtle, or as my fellow science folks would say, an Eretmochelys imbricate. I was released with a satellite transmitter on July 4, 2014 after nesting on Tortuguero National Park beach, Costa Rica. I measure 80.9 cm in curved carapace (shell) length. I've taken some time off from the world-renowned STC School of Sea Turtles to offer my expertise at the Tour de Turtles Migration. With the help of my geeky gang at Sea Turtle Conservancy, we will give everyone a lesson on the dangers of invasive species. Invasive species include animals such as raccoons, coyotes, or even dogs. While we cannot rid beaches of all invasive species, we can take some precautions to limit the impact they can have on sea turtles. Invasive species can decimate a population of sea turtles by digging up and eating their eggs or killing adult turtles. It's important that we follow specific and helpful guidelines to help stop invasive species such as: limiting the amount of trash and food left on the beach, supporting spay and neuter programs along the coast and always keeping an eye on your family pet while at the beach. Conclusively, by educating ourselves and patrolling nesting beaches, we can stop these outrageous attacks on sea turtles. It gives me great pleasure to participate in this year's Tour de Turtles, and although my speed may not break any sound barriers, wish me luck as I set off on this long migration! So my friends, go ahead and intellectually stimulate yourselves by reading more about my cause and support me in the marathon by spreading awareness to friends and family.
description: Estrella (Spanish for "star") is an adult female hawksbill sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter on July 4, 2014 from Tortuguero National Park in Costa Rica. She measured 80.9 cm in curved carapace (shell) length. She is taking part in the 2014 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, Sea Turtle Conservancy.

name: Esperanza
biography: Why hello there, Bonitas! My name's Esperanza, which means "hope" in Spanish. I'm an adult female green sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter on July 3, 2014 after nesting on Tortuguero National Park beach, Costa Rica. I measure 104.9 cm in curved carapace (shell) length. I returned to nest again on July 16, 2014. I took off from Tortuguero, Costa Rica and am swimming in the Tour de Turtles to raise awareness about the threat of egg harvesting for consumption, also known as poaching. Ay dios mio, this issue has been such a problem for mi turtle familia. For centuries, humans have been seeking out turtle eggs because in some parts of the world they are considered to be a delicacy. After me and my fellow turtle amigos lay our eggs on the beach, we return to the sea. Poachers often disturb these nests and steal our eggs to sell for profit or even to cook and eat. This has vastly affected the turtle population, especially for endangered green sea turtles like myself. To help solve this problem, we all have to work together to raise awareness about the issue. In order for all of us to do so; don't consume turtle products, support ecotourism in places like Tortuguero that encourages saving turtles, and report any disturbances to nests. Also, put your fins together and cheer me on in the Tour de Turtles race while I swim against egg harvesting with the help of mis amigos at Contiki and TreadRight!
description: Esperanza (Spanish for "hope") is an adult female green sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter on July 3, 2014 from Tortuguero National Park in Costa Rica. She measured 104.9 cm in curved carapace (shell) length. She is taking part in the 2014 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsors, Contiki and TreadRight Foundation. Seen nesting again on July 16, 2014.

name: Coco
biography: Hello everyone, my name's Coco. I'm an adult hawksbill sea turtle released on July 20, 2014 with a satellite transmitter after nesting on the beach at Jones Bay, Nevis. I measure 88.9 cm in curved carapace (shell) length. Whoa, there's quite a crowd out here today at the Tour De Turtles event huh? This may be a little too much for me. I guess we could call me the shy gal of the bunch, an introvert of sorts. I just like to keep things inside my shell where it's safe! For the love of STC's annual Tour De Turtle's event, I'm mustering up all the confidence I have to be out here with you all and begin my migration. This year, the cause I am racing for is illegal shell trade. Oh gosh, that sounds scary doesn't it? Illegal shell trade is common within the hawksbill family because our shells are highly sought after for their beautiful pattern, which has caused us to become critically endangered. In the past 100 years, the hawksbill population has decreased by 90 percent and this is because our shells are marketable for things like jewelry and other luxurious items. I cannot imagine a life without my cozy, gold and brown shell. I believe it's crucial that we fight against this trade because it vastly affects the number of hawksbill and other turtles in our world. Along with my support from you and my sponsors at Four Season Nevis, we can educate others on the dangers of shell trade. By collaborating with conservation groups and government agencies, we can gain more trade control and place a stricter emphasis on international and regional trade agreements. This education and awareness will hopefully diminish shell trade for good. Now don't make me blush or anything, but cheer me on as I migrate for the cause of illegal shell trade!
description: Coco is an adult hawksbill sea turtle released on July 20, 2014 with a satellite transmitter after nesting on the beach at Jones Bay, Nevis. She measure 88.9 cm in curved carapace (shell) length. She is taking part in the 2014 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, Four Seasons Resort Nevis.

name: Sugar
biography: Hi friends! My name is Sugar and I'm the sweetest hawksbill you'll ever meet!  I've spent the past 20 years traveling around to lovely places like Aruba, Bahamas and St. Kitts. I recently nested on the beautiful Lover's Beach in Nevis and was persuaded to join the Tour de Turtles marathon by the wonderful people at the Four Seasons Resort Nevis. I measure 82.0 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 76.5 cm curved carapace width and I was first seen nesting in Nevis in 2007. Along with my friends at the Four Seasons,  I decided to participate in the race to help inform everyone about climate change. Climate change can cause ice caps to melt which results in rising sea levels. These rising sea levels result in the disappearance of many beaches that sea turtles need to travel back to in order to nest. Additionally, climate change can cause rising temperatures, which affects the temperature of sand on the beach. A hatchling's gender is determined by sand temperature-- Eggs in cooler parts of the nest will be males where as eggs in the upper warmer part are females. Scientists predict that the rising temperatures may cause more females to hatch, which directly affects the genetic diversity of turtles. To battle this problem, humans can use energy-saving methods of transportation, recycle more, plant vegetation along beaches to provide better nesting habitat, and look for alternative sources of energy, like solar or wind. You all seem like lovely people, so I would really appreciate if you would follow my Tour de Turtles journey and help raise awareness about the threat of climate change. Together, we can make a difference!
description: Sugar is an adult hawksbill sea turtle released on July 22, 2014 with a satellite transmitter after nesting on Lover's Beach, Nevis. She measured 82.0 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 76.5 cm curved carapace width. Sugar was first encountered nesting by the Nevis Turtle Group in 2007. She is taking part in the 2014 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, Four Seasons Resort Nevis.

name: Anna
project_name: Loggerheads from the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: Do you want to build a snowman, or for the sake of time and place, a sandcastle? Actually, never mind... unlike Princess Anna from Frozen, this Anna is more interested in winning a race than building anything over the summer. But you guys go ahead and build a sandcastle, as long as you knock it down after of course; those things can be a threat to sea turtles and entrap hatchlings on their way to the water! Anyways, I'm rambling again. I'm an adult female loggerhead released with a satellite transmitter on July 26, 2014 after nesting south of the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. I measure 84.7 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 76.0 cm in curved carapace width, and even through I have scars on my shell from an old boat strike injury, but I am so excited to be taking off from Vero Beach and migrating to my summer home in the Caribbean as part of the Tour de Turtles. It's been so nice to be out here, spending a little time away from the sargassum. I've also been working really hard to prepare for the race this year in order to raise awareness about light pollution. Light pollution is among the many problems my turtle friends and I have been dealing with for quite some time now. Bright beachfront lighting from buildings and streetlights can draw hatchlings inland and away from the ocean, which is very dangerous for them. It can also deter nesting turtles like me. This is some scary stuff so we've got to work together to find safer solutions to light. Some ways to solve these problems can be turning off unnecessary lights visible on nesting beaches or using sea turtle-friendly fixtures that shield the light from the beach! Along with these tips and keeping up with my migration, you can help root me on in the Tour de Turtle's race.
description: Anna is an adult female loggerhead sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter on July 26, 2014 from south of the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. She measured 84.7 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 76.0 cm in curved carapace width. Anna had an old boat strike wound on her shell. She is taking part in the 2014 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsors, Disney's Animal Programs and Disney's Vero Beach Resort.

name: Elsa
project_name: Loggerheads from the Archie Carr Refuge
biography:
I finally got a chance for some much needed vacation time, which has brought me to the sunshine state of Florida. I am ready to blow off some steam, release some held in aggression, and propel myself to victory in this year's Tour De Turtles event. I believe I will conquer this race the way I do everything else, fair and square. With that being said, I am here at Tour De Turtles to raise awareness about the troubling amount of plastic debris in our oceans. Who better to take on this task? To address such issues, you all must know what makes plastic debris so threatening to our waters. Items like plastic water bottles, bags, and balloons can easily make their way into the ocean. The items have toxic materials and can be easily consumed by marine life when broken down into small pieces. The consumption of this plastic debris has caused the deaths of over 100 million marine animals and can also lead to the entanglement of turtles. Solutions to these issues can be purchasing reusable grocery bags, recycling, not releasing balloons, and picking up litter. Most importantly, I am here partaking in this race to raise awareness. This is my vow to swim all the way to the Caribbean in the hopes to educate all on the dangers of plastic debris. So bring on the competition. Whether the waters are dangerous, in low tide or high tide, warm or cold, I will succeed. After all, the cold never bothered me anyway. So let it go, let it go! Or let me go, on into the ocean and show the other turtles who's really number one.

I measure 100.4 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 90.7 cm in curved carapace width.
description: Elsa is an adult female loggerhead sea turtles released with a satellite transmitter on July 26, 2014 from south of the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. She measured 100.4 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 90.7 cm in curved carapace width. She is taking part in the 2014 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, Disney Worldwide Conservation Fund

name: Shelley
project_name: Loggerheads from the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: Turtle, turtle on the wall, who's the fairest one of all? Me, of course. My name's Shelley and where I'm from, you could call me a socialite of sorts. I'm an adult female loggerhead sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter on July 27, 2014 after nesting in the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. I measure 89.9 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 85.3 cm in curved carapace width. It's only natural that the Queen Bee (or more appropriately, Queen Sea) attends one of the hottest events of the summer, Tour de Turtles.  In my opinion, the Tour de Turtles is comparable to what humans refer to as a debutante ball. It is here at the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge where only the best of the best are introduced into society and race in a migration marathon for a special cause. Not only do I want to excel in this race, but it's important for me to raise awareness about the dangers of longline fishing. I think of the ocean as my runway and plan to swim through it with grace and poise during the Tour de Turtles. How can I do that if I have to worry about being caught up in longline fishing? Alongside me during this fabulous event is my elite sponsor Ripley's Aquariums. They will be cheering me on and helping me teach everyone about some of the awful threats sea turtles face. Thankfully for them, they've got a rising star on their hands. I've got my shell looking as glamorous as ever, I'm glistening in bioluminescence, and am ready to win. Hopefully there is a tiara rewarded at the end of all this. Au revoir, mes cheris.
description: Shelley is an adult female loggerhead sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter on July 27, 2014 from the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. She measured 89.9 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 85.3 cm in curved carapace width. She is taking part in the 2014 Tour de Turtles, and was named by her sponsor, Ripley's Aquariums.

name: Melba
project_name: Loggerheads from the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: Aloha dudes and dudettes, Melba here! I'm an adult female loggerhead sea turtles released with a satellite transmitter on July 27, 2014 after nesting in the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. I measure 101.8 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 88.5 cm in curved carapace width. I'm groovin' on over to Melbourne Beach to prepare for the most epic race of the summer, the Tour de Turtles marathon. Unlike most of us loggerheads, competition isn't really my thing but I still got to get amped up for the event. Most days when I'm not fighting off the wrath of oil spills, pollution or bacteria, I prefer to keep the peace. But if it's for a tubular cause like water quality, who wouldn't want to participate? Let's face it; nothing's more important than high quality h20. For quite some time, my human buddies have been (unknowingly, I hope) allowing chemicals to run-off into my home. Even if it isn't direct pollution, bogus toxins like fertilizer and pesticides are sneakily making their way towards the ocean. Either way, I'm all about forgiveness so if we can work together along with my gnarly sponsors from the Sea Turtle Grants Program, we'll be able to fight for radical water quality. Now, I'm not in it and win it this year (though I wouldn't mind), I'm just going wax up my shell, ride the waves and see where they take me. So hang loose, enjoy the beach and let's hope I don't wipe out. Cowabonga!
description: Melba (short for Melbourne Beach) is an adult female loggerhead sea turtles released with a satellite transmitter on July 27, 2014 from the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. She measured 101.8 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 88.5 cm in curved carapace width. She is taking part in the 2014 Tour de Turtles, and was named by her sponsor, the Florida Sea Turtle License Plate.

name: Pine Tyme
biography: Hi there! My name is Pine Tyme, and I'm an 80-pound, sub-adult loggerhead sea turtle who was found floating, unable to dive near Big Pine Key, Florida Keys. Luckily, I was spotted and named by a couple of Big Pine Key residents who were surveying islands for mosquito control. They hauled me onto their small boat and took me to the The Turtle Hospital where I received excellent care. The great doctors at The Turtle Hospital took x-rays of me that showed a lot of gas in my intestines but no other injuries or problems. It took several months of treatment with a broad spectrum of antibiotics, lactulose, beano, vitamins, and a healthy diet of fish and squid. Boy, do I feel much better now! I was released from Marathon, Florida Keys, Aug. 15th (watch my release). It is important that I swim in the Tour de Turtles to raise awareness about a major threat to sea turtles: boat strikes. Many of my new turtle friends at The Turtle Hospital had been injured by boat strikes. As we all know, turtles require air to breathe. They can hold their breaths for a long time but often, when they come back up for air they are in danger of getting hit by carelessly driven boats or jet skis. Shell injuries are very serious and at times, can cause the death of sea turtles. As long as boat operators follow speed limits and water safety laws, we can help keep turtles and all marine life safe! I hope everyone will root for me during the Tour de Turtles!
description: Pine Tyme is a sub-adult loggerhead sea turtle found floating, unable to dive near Big Pine Key, Florida Keys, Florida. She measures 69.5 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and weighs nearly 80 lbs. Pine Tyme was released with a satellite transmitter from Sombrero Beach in the Florida Keys and is taking part in the 2014 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, The Turtle Hospital.

name: Kirsty
biography: I was released on August 8, 2014 in Somerset Long Bay, Bermuda.
description: Kirsty is a juvenile green sea turtle caught for the first time in Somerset Long Bay, Bermuda. She measured 66.8 cm straight carapace (shell) length and was released with a satellite transmitter on August 8, 2014. (Please note that this turtle is not "adoptable".)

name: Riffle
biography: None
description: Riffle is a juvenile green sea turtle caught in Wreck Hill, Bermuda. He had been captured once before in August 2001. Riffle measured 63.9 cm straight carapace (shell) length and was released with a satellite transmitter on August 11, 2014. (Please note that this turtle is not "adoptable".)

name: Aaron
biography: Hi there! My name is Aaron, and I'm an 80 pound sub-adult loggerhead sea turtle who was rescued in March out of a marina in Key Largo's Angler's Club where a boat captain found me floating.  I was emaciated and covered in epibiota, a parasitic organism that lives on the shell of sick turtles like me. A rehabilitation specialist picked me up in the turtle ambulance and took me to the Turtle Hospital for treatment where I received excellent care! The great doctors at The Turtle Hospital took some x-rays of me that revealed I was suffering from an intestinal impaction and lab tests showed I had a heavy load of internal parasites. For the past several months, they've been treating me with broad spectrum antibiotics, anti-parasitic medications, lactulose, vitamins, and a healthy diet of squid and fish. Boy, do I feel so much better now! Once I had gained 20 lbs. and was free of intestinal parasites, I was sent back home to the big blue off Sombrero Beach, Florida Keys. It is important that I swim in the Tour de Turtles marathon to raise awareness about a major threat to sea turtles: boat strikes. Many of my new turtle friends at The Turtle Hospital had been injured by boat strikes. As we all know, turtles require air to breathe. They can hold their breaths for a long time but when they come back up for air they are in danger of getting hit by carelessly driven boats or jet-skis. Shell injuries are very serious and at times, can cause the death of a sea turtle. As long as boats follow speed limits and water safety laws when operating any water vehicle, we can help keep turtles, and all marine life, safe! Now that I'm feeling better, I hope everyone will root for me during the Tour de Turtles marathon!
description: Aaron is a sub-adult loggerhead sea turtle.  A boat captain found Aaron floating in the marina of Key Largo Angler's Club located in the upper keys on March 19, 2015.  Aaron was emaciated, covered in epibiota, and suffered from an intestinal impaction and a heavy load of internal parasites.  Aaron was treated at the Turtle Hospital with broad spectrum antibiotics, anti-parasitic medications, lactulose, vitamins, and a healthy diet of squid and fish.  When Aaron was released with a transmitter on July 17, 2015, he measured 70.0 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and weighed of nearly 80 pounds.

name: Calypso Blue IV
biography: Hello there, or as my friends in my native country of Panama would say, hola! My name is Calypso Blue IV. Despite the rumors being spread that turtles are a slow species, I'd like to put an end to all that gossip by making my sponsors at Atlantis Resort proud and winning the Tour de Turtles race and setting a new record while I'm at it! Last year, my distant cousin Calypso Blue III came in 2nd place in the marathon by swimming 2,115 miles. Not only do I plan on winning this year, I'm also going to educate people about the dangers of commercial trawl fisheries. I keep trying to tell these fishermen that they've got the wrong gal but their gill nets keep trying to haul me away! Now, I know these guys are just trying to capture shrimp and stuff but after the 150,000 accidental injuries and deaths of my friends, something needs to be done. To show my dedication to this cause, I will be swimming across the ocean to try and put an end to the danger caused by fisheries. The least they could do is make sure to install Turtle Excluder Devices (TEDs) on their nets! Follow me on my journey by taking a look at my marathon migration map. This way, you can see my progress and cheer me on along the way. Wish me luck, although I don't need it... Us leatherbacks always win the race.
description: An adult female leatherback sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter from Soropta Beach, Panama on May 24, 2015. She measured 143.3 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 105.2 cm in curved carapace width. Calypso Blue IV is taking part in the 2015 Tour de Turtles.

name: Insolites
biography: Oh boy, oh boy, oh boy, am I excited to be participating in the 8th annual Tour de Turtles, woo-hoo! I’m Insolites the leatherback. I just love swimming and splashing and diving as deep as I can. Racing in the Tour de Turtles is going to be such a hoot! Even though crawling up the beach and laying over 100 eggs in Panama was tiring, I've had some time to rest and now have all my energy back! I'm ready to swim as far and fast as I can to help raise awareness for a good cause, and that is to teach all you folks about the dangers of invasive species predation. You can learn all about my cause on the Tour de Turtles website and find out how you can help make a difference. Humans can play a vital role in decreasing the threat of invasive species predation. Don't feed wildlife because animals will make a habit of returning to coastal areas in search for food, creating a threat to turtles; Don't leave your dogs and cats unattended; Do not leave any trash, especially garbage containing food, outside of your home, and support spay and neuter programs near coastal areas to decrease feral invasive species predation. With the help of my great and knowledgeable sponsors at Continents Insolites, we can teach everyone about my amazing species! Oh, this is going to be so much fun! Don't forget to cheer me on during my journey. I plan on swimming fast and far and becoming the ultimate champion and will even share the trophy will all my new friends!
description: An adult female leatherback sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter from Chiriqui Beach, Panama on May 26, 2015. Insolites is taking part in the 2015 Tour de Turtles.

name: Cana
biography: None
description: An adult female leatherback sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter from Chiriqui Beach, Panama on May 26, 2015. Caña is taking part in the 2015 Tour de Turtles.

name: Pawikan
biography: Why hello there, Bonitas! My name's Pawikan the green turtle, but you can call me "Pawi" for short. I took off from Tortuguero, Costa Rica and am swimming in the Tour de Turtles to raise awareness about the threat of egg harvesting for consumption, also known as poaching. Ay dios mio, this issue has been such a problem for mi turtle familia. For centuries, humans have been seeking out turtle eggs because in some parts of the world they are considered to be a delicacy. After me and my fellow turtle amigos lay our eggs on the beach, we return to the sea. Poachers often disturb these nests and steal our eggs to sell for profit or even cook. This has vastly affected the turtle population, especially for endangered green sea turtles like myself. To help solve this problem, we all have to work together to raise awareness about the issue. In order for all of us to do so; don't consume turtle products, support ecotourism in places like Tortuguero that encourages saving turtles, and report any disturbances to nests. Also, put your fins together and cheer me on in the Tour de Turtles race while I swim against egg harvesting with the help of mis amigos at Pacsafe!
description: Pawikan is an adult female green sea turtle released on July 1, 2015 with a satellite transmitter after nesting in section 3 6/8 on Tortuguero Beach, Costa Rica. She measured 107.5 cm curved carapace length. Pawikan is taking part in the 2015 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, Pacsafe.

name: Tiki
biography: Que tal, amigos?! My name is Tiki the tortuga. I'm a totally cool hawksbill sea turtle from Tortuguero, Costa Rica. In my expert opinion, us hawksbill turtles are by far the best looking so I have no doubt I will win over the hearts of all the Tour de Turtle fans. This year, the cause I am racing for is illegal shell trade. Illegal shell trade is common within the hawksbill family because our shells are highly sought after for their beautiful pattern, which has caused us to become critically endangered. In the past 100 years, the hawksbill population has decreased by 90 percent and this is because our shells are highly sought after to make things like jewelry, hair accessories and other gift items. I cannot imagine a life without my cozy, gold and brown shell. By collaborating with conservation groups and government agencies, we can gain more trade control and place a stricter emphasis on international and regional trade agreements. This education and awareness will hopefully diminish shell trade for good. But for now, it is still a real problem on the Central American beaches I visit. Along with support from my fans and my sponsors at TreadRight and Contiki, we can educate others on the dangers of shell trade.
description: Tiki is an adult female hawksbill sea turtle released on July 2, 2015 with a satellite transmitter after nesting in section 2/8 on Tortuguero Beach, Costa Rica. She measured 90.9 cm curved carapace length. Tiki is taking part in the 2015 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsors, Contiki and TreadRight Foundation.

name: Susie Q
biography: Many of you are probably familiar with Susie Q. the song but what about Susie Q. the turtle?! I'm prepared to take the world by storm and become the latest sensation in turtle conservation! With the support of my fans and sponsors at Turtle & Hughes, Inc., I have no doubt I will succeed in the Tour de Turtles race! I'm ready to swim as far and fast as I can to help raise awareness for a good cause, and that is to teach all you fans about the dangers of light pollution. Bright lights may be good for rocking out onstage to your favorite song but are definitely not good when they're near the beach. Lights from beachfront property or even street lights can disorient nesting turtles and hatchlings. You can learn more about light pollution on the Tour de Turtles website and find out how you can help make a difference. It really is easy... Make sure to install sea turtle friendly lights on any of your beachfront property and always close the blinds and shades during nesting season. With the help of my great and knowledgeable sponsors at Turtle & Hughes, Inc, we can teach everyone about going "Lights Out" for sea turtles during nesting season! And please, no autographs until after the race is over.
description: Susie Q is an adult female green sea turtle released on July 2, 2015 with a satellite transmitter after nesting on Tortuguero Beach, Costa Rica. Susie Q is taking part in the 2015 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, Turtle & Hughes, Inc..

name: Tinker Bell
project_name: Loggerheads from the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: Hi there! My name is Tinkerbell! I am so excited to be taking off from Vero Beach and migrating to my summer home in the Caribbean as part of the Tour de Turtles. I even have a little pixie dust saved up just in case I need an extra boost during my migration. I've been working really hard to prepare for the race this year in order to raise awareness about light pollution. I'm super lucky that my friends at Disney's Vero Beach Resort installed sea turtle-friendly lighting for me, but many beachfront hotels still have bright, white lights. Light pollution is a problem my turtle friends and I have been dealing with for quite some time now. Bright beachfront lighting from buildings and streetlights can draw hatchlings inland and away from the ocean, which is very dangerous for them. It can also deter nesting turtles like me. This is some scary stuff so we've got to work together to find safer solutions. Some ways to solve these problems can be turning off unnecessary lights visible on nesting beaches or using sea turtle-friendly fixtures that shield the light from the beach! Along with these tips and keeping up with my migration, you can help root me on in the Tour de Turtle's race.
description: Tinker Bell is the largest adult female loggerhead sea turtle ever released by STC with a satellite transmitter from the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. She measured 114.9 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 98.0 cm in curved carapace width. She was release on August 1, 2015 and is taking part in the 2015 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsors, Disney's Animal Programs and Disney's Vero Beach Resort.

name: Marina
project_name: Loggerheads from the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: Greetings, friends! My name is Marina, which means "from the sea." I am an expert when it comes to knowledge of the underwater world, and I plan to use my experience to navigate the ocean currents all the way to the finish line! I also am here at the Tour de Turtles to raise awareness about the troubling amount of plastic debris in our precious oceans. Items like plastic water bottles, bags, balloons, nets and fishing line can easily make their way into the ocean. These items contain toxic materials and can be accidentally consumed by marine life, especially when broken down into small pieces. The consumption of this plastic debris has caused the deaths of over 100 million of my marine animal friends and can also lead to the entanglement of turtles like me. Even though I would love to use my fairy-like abilities to control the water, I certainly can't keep all these bad items from entering it by myself! I need your help! Solutions to this issue can include: taking reusable grocery bags to the store, recycling, not releasing balloons, and picking up litter. I plan to navigate my way through rough waters all the way to the Caribbean in the hopes of educating everyone along the way about the dangers of plastic debris. I'm so glad my friends at Disney's Conservation Fund have my back, er, shell!
description: Marina is an adult female loggerhead sea turtles released with a satellite transmitter on August 1, 2015 from south of the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. She measured 107.9 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 97.2 cm in curved carapace width. She is taking part in the 2015 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, Disney Worldwide Conservation Fund.

I'm also pretty stoked because I am swimming to raise awareness about a totally tubular cause-plastic debris. Let's face it; nothing's more important than high quality h2o and spotless, sandy beaches. My buddies at Ripley's Aquarium already do a gnarly job of educating the public about the threat of plastic debris. They participate in numerous local community clean-ups and have tons of exhibits in their aquariums that educate the public about sea turtle threats. If we all work together, we'll do a totally tubular job at keeping our beaches and waterways clean. For now, I'm just going wax up my shell, ride the waves and see where they take me. So hang loose, clean up the beach, and let's hope I don't wipe out. Cowabonga, dudes!

She measured 101.9 cm in curved carapace (shell) length. She is taking part in the 2015 Tour de Turtles, and was named by her sponsor, Ripley's Aquariums.
