name: Luna
biography: Hi friends! My name is Luna and I'm the most lovable hawksbill you'll ever meet! I've spent the past 20 years traveling around to lovely places like Aruba, Bahamas and St. Kitts. I recently nested on a Beach in Nevis and was persuaded to join the Tour de Turtles marathon by the wonderful people at the Four Seasons Resort Nevis. Along with my friends at the Four Seasons, I decided to participate in the race to help inform everyone about climate change. Climate change can cause ice caps to melt which results in rising sea levels. These rising sea levels result in the disappearance of many beaches that sea turtles need to travel back to in order to nest. Additionally, climate change can cause rising temperatures, which affects the temperature of sand on the beach. A hatchling's gender is determined by sand temperature-- Eggs in cooler parts of the nest will be males whereas eggs in the upper warmer part are females. Scientists predict that the rising temperatures may cause more females to hatch, which directly affects the genetic diversity of turtles. To battle this problem, humans can use energy-saving methods of transportation, recycle more, plant vegetation along beaches to provide better nesting habitat, and look for alternative sources of energy, like solar or wind. You all seem like lovely people so I would really appreciate if you would follow my Tour de Turtles journey and help raise awareness about the threat of climate change. Together, we can make a difference!
description: Luna is an adult hawksbill sea turtle released on July 12, 2015 with a satellite transmitter after nesting on the beach at Jones Bay, Nevis. She measure 78.0 cm in curved carapace (shell) length. This was Luna's third nest of the season, she had previously nested two times on Lover's Beach, Nevis. She is taking part in the 2015 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, Four Seasons Resort Nevis.

name: Millie
biography: Hello my fellow heroes! You can call me Millie the Marvelous! Between my island hopping adventures, I spend my time fighting off the wrath of oil spills, pollution and harmful toxins. I was honored when my friends at the Four Seasons Resort asked if I would join their heroic team in the Tour de Turtles to raise awareness about water quality. Sea turtles like me spend the majority of their lives in the water so we need to make sure their habitat is just as healthy and clean as a nesting beach. For quite some time, many humans have been (unknowingly, I hope) allowing chemicals to run-off into my home. Even if it isn't direct pollution, harmful toxins like fertilizer and pesticides are sneakily making their way towards the ocean. Even though I act like I can save the world all by myself, I really need your help for this mission. You can help by never littering and always properly disposing of hazardous waste; using less chemical fertilizers and opting for natural compost instead; and buying organically produced food. Do you accept this mission? I’ll see you at the finish line!
description: Millie is an adult hawksbill sea turtle released on July 13, 2015 with a satellite transmitter after nesting on the beach at Oualie Beach, Nevis. She measure 95.0 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and is one of the largest hawksbills nesting in Nevis. She is taking part in the 2015 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, Four Seasons Resort Nevis.

name: Amie
project_name: Tracking Turtles from Florida's Gulf Coast
biography: Hi Friends! My name is Amie which stands for Anna Maria Island Elementary. This is the first time any turtle from my home beach of Anna Maria Island has ever participated in the prestigious Tour de Turtles program and I am honored to have been the chosen turtle! My friends in the AMI Turtle Watch group do a great job monitoring and protecting my favorite beaches but they need your help to raise awareness about a serious threat turtles are facing... Beach Erosion. One way to address beach erosion is through beach nourishment. Nourishment consists of pumping, trucking or otherwise depositing sand on a beach to replace what has been lost to erosion. While beach nourishment is often preferable to armoring, it can negatively impact sea turtles if the sand is too compacted for turtles to nest in or if the sand imported is drastically different from native beach sediments, thereby potentially affecting nest-site selection, digging behavior, incubation temperature and the moisture content of nests. Anna Maria Island has undergone a lot of beach renourishment lately so the turtle watch folks are keeping a close eye on turtle nesting and hatching trends. Since I successfully nested once already, I'm ready to crank up the speed and bring the trophy home to Anna Maria Island!
description: Amie is an adult female loggerhead sea turtles released on June 23, 2015 with a satellite transmitter after nesting on Coquina Beach. She is taking part in the 2015 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, Anna Maria Island Turtle Watch.

name: Sea Venture
biography: None
description: Sea Venture is a juvenile green sea turtle caught in Fort Saint Catherine, Bermuda. He has not been previously captured. Sea Venture measured 61.0 cm straight carapace (shell) length and was released with a satellite transmitter on August 14, 2015. (Please note that this turtle is not "adoptable".)

name: Renaissance
biography: None
description: Renaissance is a juvenile green sea turtle caught in Wreck Hill, Bermuda. He measured 66.5 cm straight carapace (shell) length and was released with a satellite transmitter on August 17, 2015. (Please note that this turtle is not "adoptable".)

name: Ozzy
biography: None
description: On November 23, 2013, Ozzy was found caught up in fishing line and a crab trap rope in open water off of Pasco County. The entanglement caused a severe laceration around the base of her right front flipper, which resulted in her immediate transportation to Clearwater Marine Aquarium for treatment.  Shortly after arrival, a spiral fracture through Ozzy's humerus was identified in addition to the serious laceration.  Through therapy and wound care, she regained her strength under the watchful eye of the turtle team.  After passing several veterinary tests to assess her deep water swimming strength and her ability to hunt for food, Ozzy was cleared for release from Clearwater Beach on September 9, 2015.

name: Calypso Blue V
biography: Calypso Blue V is the name, and spreading awareness is my game! Listen up friends, I want to let you in on a little thing called trawling in commercial fishing. This large weird-looking net gets dragged behind a boat or two and basically catches everything in its way, including us sea turtles. We get all tangled up in these nets and even if we’re able to get away, we can end up with some serious injuries from the equipment. The great folks at Atlantis Resort have already pledged to help me out. Now I need you to cheer me on in this race so our cause can be heard and we can bring awareness to this serious problem! Sea turtles should not be caught in ANY nets. I mean, come on guys, this isn’t Pokémon, we don’t “gotta catch ‘em all!”
description: An adult female leatherback sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter from Soropta Beach, Panama on May 30, 2016. She measured 149.7 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 108.1 cm in curved carapace width. She was previously flipper tagged on Soropta Beach. Calypso Blue V was seen nesting again 9 days later on Soropta Beach.

name: Lady Aurelia
biography: Turtle, turtle on the wall, who’s the fairest one of all? Why, it’s me, of course! My name’s Lady Aurelia and I reign over one of the most important nesting beaches in Panama. It’s only natural that I would participate in the hottest event of the summer, the Tour de Turtles.  Not only do I want to excel in this race, but it’s important for me to raise awareness about the dangers of invasive species predation. The nests in my territory are frequently predated by stray dogs. I’m afraid if I don’t find a solution, my people might just overthrow me! Alongside me during this fabulous event is my elite sponsor, the New England Cord Blood Bank. They will be cheering me on and helping me teach everyone about the awful threats sea turtles face. I’ve got my shell looking as glamorous as ever, I’m glistening in bioluminescence, and am ready to win. Hopefully there is a tiara rewarded at the end of all this.
description: An adult female leatherback sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter from Soropta Beach, Panama on May 28, 2016. She measured 151.1 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 112.6 cm in curved carapace width. She was originally flipper tagged by beach monitors on Pacuare beach in Costa Rica, over 75 miles (120 km) away. Lady Aurelia was seen nesting again two more times, about 9 days apart, on Soropta Beach.

name: Tortuga Turista
biography: Hola! Me llamo Tortuga Turista! I’ve been in training ever since I was tagged in Panama on June 9th. Since then, I’ve been stretching my flippers and perfecting my dive to take on the other competitors in the Tour de Turtles. I’m very lucky to have the support of the USF Patel College of Global Sustainability behind me! Like a true sustainable tourist, I’ve already visited the coastal waters of six countries (Panama, Costa Rica, Nicaragua, Honduras, Belize, and Mexico.)  I’m proud to say my travels have been quite sustainable, producing no carbon emissions, no waste to land fill, no depletion of water resources, no disruption of any cultural heritage, and no negative impact on biodiversity. Where should I travel next?
description: An adult female leatherback sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter from Chiriqui Beach, Panama on May 31, 2016. She measured 152.5 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 102.8 cm in curved carapace width. She was previously flipper tagged by beach monitors on Chiriqui Beach earlier in 2016 nesting season. Tortuga Turista was seen nesting again 9 days later on Chiriqui Beach.

name: Kreacher
biography: Hey there, I’m Kreacher! (My parents were big Harry Potter fans back in the day.) I was rescued off Clearwater Beach by the turtle team at Clearwater Marine Aquarium (CMA). According to them, I was discovered floating and distressed with moderate edema—or swelling caused by fluid retention. Results of a CT scan revealed shells in my esophagus and gastro-intestinal track, causing me buoyancy issues and MAJOR discomfort. Boy was I was lucky CMA found me! Now that I’ve made a stellar recovery, I’m ready to race and tell everyone about boat strikes, a huge threat to sea turtles. I mean, HUGE. Even though I’m just a sub-adult, I can take down the more experienced pros and win this thing. Vote for me in the People’s Choice Race to help make Clearwater great again!
description: Kreacher is a sub-adult loggerhead sea turtle and weighs nearly 100 pounds. Kreacher was rescued a half a mile offshore Clearwater Beach on May 8th. She was found floating and distressed with moderate edema. She received a round of Total Parenteral Nutrition before moving to tube feeding and finally solid food. By the end of May Kreacher showed great improvement while at CMA and was selected to receive a satellite tag. Kreacher weighs over 43 kg and measured 68.0 cm in straight carapace (shell) length and 65.4 cm straight carapace width.

name: Fleming
biography: Hey there everyone, Fleming here! I’m totally stoked to be a part of the Tour de Turtles this year! In my opinion I’m the raddest competitor in this thing! I’m not a nesting female like most of the turtles in the marathon. I was actually found by a boat captain who stopped to help me out off of Fleming Key in the Florida Keys. I was tangled in fishing line AND covered in some nasty tumors. Totally not tubular. My friends at the Turtle Hospital helped get me back on my flippers since I wasn’t doing so hot. Now, I’ve had a year to recover and I’m as good as new! I’m racing to spread the word about Poor Water Quality because clean water is crucial for sea turtles like me and my non-flippered friends. Let’s hear it for ya boy Fleming!
description: Fleming was rescued in March, 2015 just 200 feet off of Fleming Key in Key West where a boat captain found him entangled in fishing line, tethered to a piece of pvc piping. Fleming’s body and eyes were covered in Fibropapilloma tumors. Fleming treatment at the Turtle Hospital included five tumor removal surgeries, antibiotics, anti-parasitic medications, vitamins, and a healthy diet of squid and greens. Fleming is strong and tumor free, measuring 73.4 cm curved carapace length, 73.8 cm curved carapace width, and weighing 84 lbs. Fleming was fitted with a small transmitter on July 22, 2016 and released from Sombrero Beach, Florida Keys, FL.

name: Esperanza
biography: Hola amigos! This is the first time any turtle from my home country of Cuba has participated in the prestigious Tour de Turtles program and I am honored to have been selected! While this race is sure going to be a shell-load of fun, I am swimming to shed some light on a serious problem that’s no bueno for all my fellow turtles. Marine pollution, like oil spills, is bad news for me and all my ocean amigos. Now, although we sea turtles are pretty tough when it comes to resisting the immediate physical damage from oil spills, we are still at risk of eating contaminated food. This is an issue muy grande because we LOVE nuestra comida deliciosa! Also, we nesting mamacitas are put even more at risk when we visit oiled shores because it puts our future niñitos in danger once they leave the nest! Ay dios mío! Please support me in the race so we can beat the toughest competitor… Pollution!
description: An adult green sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter from Guanahacabibes Natural Park, Cuba on June 29, 2016. She measured 107.0 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 93.0 cm in curved carapace width, and laid 152 eggs. Esperanza is taking part in the 2016 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, the Sea Life Trust.

name: Julia
biography: Que tal amigos? Me llamo Julia! My interests include swimming marathons, drinking café con leche, dancing, and eating a strictly vegetarian diet. I’ve been training hard for my next marathon so I’m spending a lot of time in the water, as most adult sea turtles do. You know what I’ve noticed recently? It is totally NOT sanitary! I heard through the grapevine that humans have been allowing chemicals and waste to run-off in MY training area. Even if it isn’t direct pollution, harmful toxins like fertilizer and pesticides are sneakily making their way towards the ocean. I used my connections to hook up with The Turtle Hospital and they’re going to help us put a stop to this madness. Afterall, you can’t expect me to swim in this dirty water! Si se puede!
description: An adult green sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter from Guanahacabibes Natural Park, Cuba on June 29, 2016. She measured 103.0 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 93.0 cm in curved carapace width, and laid 92 eggs. Julia is taking part in the 2016 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, The Turtle Hospital in Marathon, Florida Keys.

name: Pebbles
biography: Como están Señoras y señores? Pebbles is here to tell you about this BIG problem we have back home that is seriously messing with our pura vida. You probably already know that many animales find our huevos tasty, but did you know that humans are some of those animales!? After we are finished with the long, hard task of nesting, sometimes bad humans will come along and steal our little bebes! This is a huge blow not only to my heart, but especially to our struggling population. Now I already know my muy rapido swimming skills are going to win me this race, but I’m going to need more than swimming skills to beat these bad guys! Luckily I have the amazing team at DivinityLA behind the cause as well. Let’s go kick some shell!
description: Pebbles is an adult female green sea turtle released on July 9, 2016 with a satellite transmitter after nesting in on Tortuguero Beach, Costa Rica. She measured 109.4 cm in curved carapace (shell) length. She is taking part in the 2016 Tour de Turtles and was named by sponsor, DivinityLA.

name: Emma
biography: None
description: Emma is an adult female green sea turtle released on July 10, 2016 with a satellite transmitter after nesting in on Tortuguero Beach, Costa Rica. She measured 106.6 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 99.5 cm in straight carapace length. Emma laid 68 eggs in her nest and she was originally flipper tagged in 2013.

name: Sundrop
biography: Well hello there beautiful! Oh wait, that’s just my shell in the mirror… *Ahem* Well hello darlings, Sundrop here! I don’t know if you’ve noticed yet but my shell happens to be a swimming masterpiece. Unfortunately, instead of just admiring the artwork some humans want to take my gorgeous shell and make it into art of their own, like jewelry! While I’m all for a good statement necklace, I don’t think hurting sea turtles is a very nice statement, do you? I sure hope your answer is no and you join me and my loyal friends at the Four Seasons Resort Nevis in spreading the word about the illegal shell trade! Remember, you can look but you can’t touch!
description: Sundrop is an adult hawksbill sea turtle released on July 18, 2016 with a satellite transmitter after nesting on the beach at Lovers Beach, Nevis.  She measured 77.3 cm curved carapace (shell) length. Sundrop is taking part in the 2016 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, Four Seasons Resort Nevis.

name: Sylvia
biography: Hello there! My name is Sylvia! I was named in honor of the Four Seasons Resort’s 25th Anniversary in Nevis. And now I’m prepared to take the world by storm and become the latest sensation in turtle conservation! With the support of my fans and sponsors at the Four Seasons Nevis, I have no doubt I will succeed in the Tour de Turtles race! I'm ready to swim as fast as I can to help raise awareness for a good cause, and that is to teach all you fans about the dangers of climate change. Because of climate change, sea levels are rising, resulting in the disappearance of many nesting beaches. To battle this problem, humans can use energy-saving methods of transportation, plant vegetation along beaches to provide better nesting habitat, and use more solar or wind energy. You all seem like great fans so I would really appreciate if you would help me out and follow my Tour de Turtles journey. But please, no autographs until after the race is over.
description: Sylvia is an adult hawksbill sea turtle released on July 18, 2016 with a satellite transmitter after nesting on the beach at Lovers Beach, Nevis.  She measured 86.8 cm curved carapace (shell) length. Sylvia is taking part in the 2016 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, Four Seasons Resort Nevis.

name: Bailey
project_name: Loggerheads from the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: Hi, friends! My name is Bailey! Some say I have a flair for the dramatic, but really I just want to make sure everyone knows how important my cause is. Plastic debris is a ginormous threat to marine life, especially for sea turtles and marine mammals. Items like plastic water bottles, bags, and balloons can easily make their way into the ocean, where they break down into small pieces. Accidentally eating this plastic has caused the deaths of over 100 million of my marine animal friends. I certainly can’t keep all these bad items from entering the ocean by myself! I need your help! Take reusable grocery bags to the store, never release balloons, and always pick up litter. You can also follow me on my journey and help me spread the word! I know my friends at Disney’s Conservation Fund will have my back, er, shell!
description: Bailey is an adult female loggerhead sea turtle to be released with a satellite transmitter on July 30, 2016 from south of the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. She measured 100.0 cm curved carapace (shell) length and 88.6 cm curved carapace width. She is taking part in the 2016 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, Disney Conservation Fund.

name: Destiny
project_name: Loggerheads from the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: Hiya! I’m Destiny! I’ve been working really hard to prepare for the race this year in order to raise awareness about light pollution. Vero Beach is my favorite spot to nest for many reasons. One of those is because Disney’s Vero Beach Resort installed sea turtle-friendly lighting for me! But many beachfront hotels and condos still have bright, white lights. I have enough trouble seeing as it is, I don’t need pesky bright lights confusing me! Bright beachfront lighting can also draw little hatchlings inland and away from the ocean, which is very dangerous. This is some scary stuff so we’ve got to work together to make beaches safe for turtles. Make sure to turn off unnecessary lights visible on nesting beaches or use sea turtle-friendly fixtures to help. My game plan is to navigate my way down to the Caribbean and educate everyone along the way about the dangers of light pollution. I might not be the most graceful turtle in the bunch, but I’d say winning the Tour de Turtles is my “Destiny.” :)
description: Destiny is an adult female loggerhead sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter on July 30, 2016 from south of the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. She measured 91.2 cm curved carapace (shell) length and 82.1.6 cm curved carapace width. She is taking part in the 2016 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsors, Disney's Animal Programs and Disney's Vero Beach Resort.

name: Leonora
project_name: Loggerheads from the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: My name is Leonora and I’m the most lovable loggerhead you’ll ever meet! I’ve spent the past 20 years traveling around to lovely places like the Bahamas and The Florida Keys. I recently nested on a beautiful beach in the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge and was just too tickled at the idea of joining the Tour de Turtles. My new human friends at Ripley’s Aquariums also asked for my help to raise awareness about a serious threat… Beach erosion. Doesn’t that sound frightening? Almost half of Florida’s nesting beaches are critically eroded. Beach renourishment is the primary strategy to combat coastal erosion in Florida. While this can help, it must be carried out correctly and under strict guidelines that ensure the "new beach" is compatible for successful nesting. The STC is keeping a close eye on things at home, so I think it’s about time for me to skedaddle on out of here and spread the word!
description: An adult female loggerhead sea turtle to be released with a satellite transmitter on July 31, 2016 from the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. She measured 101.0 cm curved carapace (shell) length and 92.2 cm curved carapace width. Leonora is taking part in the 2016 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, Ripley's Aquariums.

name: Turpac
project_name: Loggerheads from the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: Sup kids, the name’s Turpac. The peeps over at Pacsafe recruited me to join their Tour de Turtles Team. What can I say? I’m basically a living legend in the Archie Carr Refuge these days. They need me to swim as far as I can to help spread the word about some whack longline fisheries. To help out the cause, I wrote a little rap I’d like to share with everyone, “When I talk about turtles all you see is the struggle/ When I tell you there’s a longline, you tell me it’s trouble.” Do you like it? I ain’t mad atcha if you don’t. I’ll admit the chorus needs some work, but that’s no excuse not to cheer for me during the race! Help me spread the word about the dangers of longline fisheries. I want to make sure we keep spending most our lives “living in a turtles’ paradise.”
description: Turpac is an adult female loggerhead sea turtle to be released on July 31, 2016 with a satellite transmitter after nesting in the Archie Carr Refuge. Florida. She measured 105.0 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 93.9 cm in curved carapace width. She is taking part in the 2015 Tour de Turtles, and was named by her sponsor, Pacsafe.

name: Hardy
biography: None
description: Hardy is a juvenile green sea turtle caught in Somerset Long Bay, Bermuda. He measured 67.1 cm straight carapace (shell) length and was released with a satellite transmitter on August 10, 2016.

name: Aquarius
biography: None
description: Aquarius is a juvenile green sea turtle caught in Somerset Long Bay, Bermuda. He measured 58.5 cm straight carapace (shell) length and was released with a satellite transmitter on August 15, 2016.

name: Doppler
biography: None
description: Doppler is a juvenile green sea turtle caught in Long Bay, Bermuda. He measured 57.1 cm straight carapace (shell) length and was released with a satellite transmitter on August 18, 2016.

name: Chief
project_name: Adult Green Turtles of the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: None
description: Chief is a 90.7 cm male green turtle named for Dave Hochberg, longtime friend of UCF and Chairman of the Board of the Sea Turtle Preservation Society in Indialantic, Florida.

name: Iris
project_name: Adult Green Turtles of the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: None
description: "Iris" (pronounced "Eer-us") is a 99.5 cm female originally tagged by the UCF group in 2004. Seen twice in that season, she had not been seen since. The Sea Turtle Preservation Society of Indialantic, FL provided this tag, and chose to name this turtle after Iris Reinhold, a member of their group.

name: Daisy
biography: None
description: Daisy is a loggerhead sea turtle rehabilitated by the Bermuda Aquarium Museum and Zoo (BAMZ). The loggerhead was first brought to BAMZ in December, 2015 suffering from pneumonia and serious lung issues. After a CT scan at King Edward VII Memorial Hospital revealed the presence of a large fishing hook, doctors were able to remove the hook from Daisy's trachea. Once Daisy had recovered and was ready for release, BAMZ staff attached a satellite tag and released her at North Rock, near the edge of the Bermuda Platform, on July 18, 2016.

name: Atamar
biography: None
description: None

name: Xeno
biography: None
description: Xeno (short for Xenophilius) is a sub-adult loggerhead sea turtle rescued about 15 miles offshore Clearwater Beach on September 17, 2016. She was found floating and unable to dive. X-rays showed that Xeno's intestine was compacted by an extensive amount of shell-like material. CMA provided treatment that included lots of liquid, helping Xeno pass the material, which turned about to be nearly 5 lbs of crushed shell. Just over a month later, Xeno showed great improvement and was selected to receive a satellite tag. Xeno measured 73.4 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 57.6 cm straight carapace width.

name: Peanut
project_name: Satellite Tracking Sea Turtles at Gumbo Limbo Nature Center
biography: On May 1, 2016, sightings of a large sea turtle near Peanut Island were reported to Florida Fish & Wildlife (FWC). Snorkelers in the area reported the adult loggerhead lingering on the nearshore reefs and appearing to be in poor condition. Photographs from the snorkelers confirmed the extreme emaciation of this turtle and efforts were undertaken by FWC officials to transport the sick turtle to a rehabilitation facility. Peanut, named after the island she was rescued on, arrived at Gumbo Limbo Nature Center's Sea Turtle Rehabilitation Facility in critical condition and received immediate medical care. After 7 months of intense rehabilitation, Peanut has been cleared for release by our veterinarian. She was released on December 6, 2016 from Boca Raton, Florida. We're excited to see where her journey takes her!
description: On May 1, 2016, sightings of a large loggerhead sea turtle near Peanut Island were reported to Florida Fish & Wildlife (FWC). Efforts were undertaken by FWC officials to transport the sick turtle to a rehabilitation facility. Peanut, named after the island she was rescued on, arrived at Gumbo Limbo Nature Center's Sea Turtle Rehabilitation Facility in critical condition and received immediate medical care. After 7 months of intense rehabilitation, Peanut was released on December 6, 2016 from Boca Raton, Florida.

name: Five-oh
project_name: Satellite Tracking Sea Turtles at Gumbo Limbo Nature Center
biography: On Easter night, March 27, 2016, the rehabilitation team received a phone call from the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission about an injured sea turtle and they immediately raced to the scene. Five-oh, affectionately named in honor of the rescuers, was discovered by a local resident and rescued by members of the City of Boca Raton Police Department. Responding officers carefully retrieved the turtle from the intracoastal waters while using a floating boat lift as a raft to get down to the turtle from the elevated seawall. The injuries were severe. Several officers worked together to keep the turtle upright while pulling him out of the water. They tried to keep Five-oh as stable as possible due to the large open gash in the shell, exposing internal organs. Quick thinking officers applied pressure to stem the loss of blood until the Gumbo Limbo rescue team arrived. At first glance, the Rehabilitation team thought the chances of survival were slim due to the severity of the lacerations. After admitting Five-oh, the Rehab team quickly realized that this turtle had too much fight to give up. With countless hours of triage, slow and steady treatments including Wound-Vac negative pressure therapy, Five-oh has made a full recovery. It has been almost one year since arrival, but this little turtle is ready to give the ocean one more shot! Thanks to the collaborative efforts of the Boca Police Department, Palm Beach Veterinary Specialists, Palm Beach Zoo, Friends of Gumbo Limbo, and our Sea Turtle Rehabilitation Team, Five-oh was released off of a Boca Raton beach after almost one year of rehabilitation!
description: On Easter night, March 27, 2016, Five-oh, affectionately named in honor of the rescuers, was discovered by a local resident and rescued by members of the City of Boca Raton Police Department. Responding officers tried to keep Five-oh as stable as possible due to the large open gash in the shell, exposing internal organs. With countless hours of triage, slow and steady treatments, Five-oh made a full recovery. Thanks to the collaborative efforts of the Boca Police Department, Palm Beach Veterinary Specialists, Palm Beach Zoo, Friends of Gumbo Limbo, and our Sea Turtle Rehabilitation Team, Five-oh was released on March 9, 2017 off of Boca Raton, FL after almost one year of rehabilitation!

name: Soropta
biography: Hola! Me llamo es Soropta. I am named after the remote beach in Panama that I come from! Every year I come back to this beach to nest, and let me tell you, it is hard work. It’s not easy getting this big, beautiful body up on a beach, finding the perfect spot to nest, digging the egg chamber, laying eggs, and then dragging myself back into the water! Even after all of this work, some strange creatures like dogs, raccoons, and boars have the NERVE to dig up MY nest! You can make sure all of my work doesn’t go to waste by keeping an eye on your pets, picking up trash around your beachfront home, and supporting spay and neuter programs.
description: An adult female leatherback sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter from Soropta Beach, Panama on May 28, 2017. She measured 149.2 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 108.4 cm in curved carapace width. She was previously flipper tagged.

name: Soca
biography: Hi there, my name is Soca! I am from Soropta, Panama, but you could say I’m a world traveler. I rarely stay in one place at one time – there is just too much to see out there in that great blue ocean. That’s why I’m so excited to be racing in the Tour de Turtles! In my travels, I have seen a lot of amazing things, and some not so amazing things, like commercial trawl fisheries. Commercial trawl fisheries are these big boats that drag giant nets behind them, catching all kinds of creatures. I’ve been lucky that I haven’t gotten stuck in one yet, but it would be very easy for me to get trapped in the net! To make sure other leatherbacks like me don’t get stuck in these nets, you can make sure you’re eating sustainably sourced fish, support companies and countries that use Turtle Excluder Devices on trawl boats, and to petition government officials to keep up with boat inspections to make sure fishermen are following the rules! That way, I can continue living my dream and travel the globe!
description: Soca is an adult female leatherback sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter from Soropta Beach, Panama on May 27, 2017. She measured 142.4 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 107.5 cm in curved carapace width. She had a small indent in the end of her carapace and was previously flipper tagged in May, 2015. Soca was named by her sponsor, Atlantis Paradise Island Resort, and took part in the 2017 Tour de Turtles.

name: Tortuga Turista II
biography: Hola! Me llamo Tortuga Turista! I’ve been busy training all summer after I was tagged in Panama on May 31st. Since then, I’ve been stretching my flippers and perfecting my dive to take on the other competitors in the Tour de Turtles. I’m very lucky to have the support of the USF Patel College of Global Sustainability behind me! Like a true sustainable tourist, I’ve already visited the coastal waters of six countries (Panama, Costa Rica, Nicaragua, Honduras, Belize, and Mexico.)  I’m proud to say my travels have been quite sustainable producing no carbon emissions, no waste to land fill, no depletion of water resources, no disruption of any cultural heritage, and no negative impact on biodiversity. Where should I travel next? I’m thinking the Gulf of Mexico!
description: Tortuga Turista II is an adult female leatherback sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter from Chiriqui Beach, Panama on May 31, 2017. She measured 141.2 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 104.8 cm in curved carapace width. She was previously flipper tagged while nesting on a different beach, but has been seen nesting on Chiriqui Beach in 2007 and 2010. Tortuga Turista II was named by her sponsor, USF Patel College of Global Sustainability and Blue Community Consortium, and took part in the 2017 Tour de Turtles.

name: Marina
biography: Hola! Me llamo Marina! I just traveled over 1,000 miles to lay my eggs on the beautiful beaches of Panama. You wouldn’t believe the things I’ve seen along the way! Ay dios mío! This one time, I passed by a line of really sharp shiny things, como se dice? Ah, fishing hooks! I later learned they were for longline fishing and that boats lay out miles of hooks to get a certain species of fish. Están loco! What happens is they accidentally end up catching things like sharks, birds, turtles, and other species of fish they don’t want. Sometimes they will just throw us back. But other times, it is too late and my turtle friends get tangled in the fishing line and drown. But not to fear! My friends at Certina have our backs; help them root for me to win this Tour de Turtles race so we can fight against the longline fisheries impacts on our ocean!
description: An adult female leatherback sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter from Chiriqui Beach, Panama on May 31, 2017. She measured 151.1 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 107.6 cm in curved carapace width. She was previously flipper tagged earlier in 2017.

name: Lincoln
biography: Hello my good people! I’m Lincoln the Leatherback. My sponsors at The Explorers Club named me after U.S. President Abraham Lincoln not because we look alike, but because we are both wise and noble. We also both happen to have an affinity for top hats, but that’s a different story... Like my idol President Lincoln, I too am ready to fight for a noble cause! Presently, my fellow marine comrades are suffering because of a man-made problem… Plastic debris. I can’t tell you how many times I’ve gone out for jellyfish only to end up with a plastic bag in my stomach instead. It’s preposterous what some humans are doing to our planet! Sorry if that sounds harsh, but I’m just being an Honest Abe! That’s why I need you all to support me in this year’s Tour de Turtles race and help me win the war on plastic once and for all!
description: Lincoln is an adult female leatherback sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter from Chiriqui Beach, Panama on May 31, 2017. She measured 151.3 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 111.0 cm in curved carapace width. She was previously flipper tagged while nesting on a different beach, but has been seen nesting on Chiriqui Beach in 2006, 2009 and 2011. Lincoln was named by her sponsor, The Explorer's Club, and is taking part in the 2017 Tour de Turtles.

name: Mandalay II
project_name: Chiriquí Beach, Panama, Hawksbill Tracking Project
biography: Mandalay II (locally known as Berigo, the name of an important Nobe village), is an adult female hawksbill sea turtle that was encountered nesting on May 30, 2017, on Chiriquí Beach. She measured 86.6 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 77.1 cm curved carapace width. She flipper tagged with tags #CH7627 and #CH7628 by STC researchers. A satellite tag was applied after she finished nesting.
description: Mandalay II (locally known as Berigo, the name of an important Nobe village), is an adult female hawksbill sea turtle that was encountered nesting on May 30, 2017, on Chiriquí Beach. She measured 86.6 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 77.1 cm curved carapace width. She flipper tagged with tags #CH7627 and #CH7628 by STC researchers. A satellite tag was applied after she finished nesting. Mandalay II was named by her sponsor, Shark Reef Aquarium, and is taking part in the 2017 Tour de Turtles.

name: Eliza Ann
project_name: Tracking Turtles from Florida's Gulf Coast
biography: Hi, I’m Eliza Ann. I’m pretty well versed in the music scene so I like to think of myself as quite the music buff. When Rihanna said to Shine Bright Like a Diamond, she most definitely was not referring to your porchlight on your beachfront property! When I come up to nest and I’m Blinded by the Light, it makes it hard for me to find a spot to lay my eggs. Sometimes I may even get confused and crawl the wrong way! It takes a lot of energy to crawl around on the beach at night. This is why I’m so thankful that Anna Maria Island Turtle Watch and Waterline Marina Resort have decided to help fight against the threat of light pollution! So join us and keep it dark All Night Long (all night).
description: Eliza Ann is an adult female loggerhead sea turtles released on June 20, 2017 with a satellite transmitter after nesting on Coquina Beach. She measured 109.5 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 110.7 cm in curved carapace width. Eliza Ann is taking part in the 2017 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsors, Anna Maria Island Turtle Watch & Waterline Marina and Resort.

name: Onda
biography: Hola amigos! This is only the second year any turtle from my home country of Cuba has participated in the prestigious Tour de Turtles program and I am honored to have been selected! While this race is sure to be a shell-load of fun, I am mainly swimming to shed some light on a serious problem that’s no bueno for all my fellow turtles. Commercial longline fisheries are bad news for me and all my ocean amigos. I even got hooked myself once!  While I was getting my fancy new satellite transmitter attached this summer, it was discovered that I had a large fishing hook in my front right flipper. Ay dios mío!  Luckily, with the assistance of staff from The Turtle Hospital, STC staff were able to safely remove the hook and I was just fine. But many of my friends are not as lucky as me! So please support me in the race so we can beat the toughest competitor… longline fisheries!
description: Onda (Spanish for wave) is an adult green sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter from Guanahacabibes Natural Park, Cuba on July 3, 2017. She measured 96.0 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 80.0 cm in curved carapace width. During the satellite attachment process, it was discovered that Onda had a large fishing hook in her front right flipper. With the assistance of staff from The Turtle Hospital in Marathon, Florida Keys, STC staff were able to safely remove the hook. Onda is taking part in the 2017 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, the Sea Life Trust.

name: Tina
biography: Que tal amigos? Me llamo Tina! I am one of two Cuban turtles participating in the race. My interests include swimming marathons, drinking café con leche, dancing, and eating a strictly vegetarian diet. I’ve been training hard for my next marathon so I’m spending a lot of time in the water, as most adult sea turtles do. You know what I’ve noticed recently? It is totally not sanitary! I heard through the grapevine that humans have been allowing chemicals and waste to run-off in MY training area. Even if it isn’t direct pollution, harmful toxins like fertilizer and pesticides are sneakily making their way towards the ocean. I used my connections to hook up with The Turtle Hospital and they’re going to help us put a stop to this madness. After all, you can’t expect me to swim in this dirty water! Si se puede!
description: Tina is an adult green sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter from Guanahacabibes Natural Park, Cuba on July 4, 2017. She measured 102.0 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 90.0 cm in curved carapace width. Tina has returned to nest three more times at Guanahacabibes this summer since having the satellite transmitter attached. Tina is taking part in the 2017 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, The Turtle Hospital in Marathon, Florida Keys.

name: Sanchez
biography: Oh boy, oh boy, oh boy, am I excited to be participating in the 10th annual Tour de Turtles, woo-hoo! I’m Sanchez the green turtle. I just love swimming and splashing and eating as much sea grass as I can! Racing in the Tour de Turtles is going to be such a hoot! Even though crawling up the beach and laying almost 100 eggs in Tortuguero was tiring, I’ve had some time to rest and now have all my energy back. I’m ready to swim as far and fast as I can to help raise awareness for a good cause, and that is to teach all you folks about the dangers of climate change. Because sea turtles use both marine and terrestrial habits, the effects of climate change are likely to have a devastating impact on us. How scary does that sound?! Climate change affects nesting beaches, coastal habitat, gender ratio of hatchlings and more! With the help of my great and knowledgeable sponsors at World Nomads, we can teach everyone about how to help me and my friends. Oh, this is going to be so much fun! Don’t forget to cheer me on during my journey. I plan on swimming fast and far and becoming the ultimate champion. I can’t wait to share the trophy will all my new friends!
description: Sanchez is an adult female green sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter on August 7, 2017 from Tortuguero National Park in Costa Rica. She measured 108.0 cm in straight carapace (shell) length and was named by her sponsor, World Nomads, and is taking part in the 2017 Tour de Turtles.

name: Tilly
biography: Hello there! My name is Tilly, but I’m commonly referred to as “Fiesty Tilly.” I’m prepared to put up a fight to win this race and spread the word about sea turtle conservation! With the support of my fans and sponsors at the Four Seasons Nevis, I have no doubt I will succeed in the Tour de Turtles race! I have just been rearing to go and promise to swim as fast as I can to help raise awareness for a good cause, educating people about the dangers of climate change. Because of climate change, sea levels are rising, resulting in the disappearance of many nesting beaches. To battle this problem, humans can use energy-saving methods of transportation, plant vegetation along beaches to provide better nesting habitat, and use more solar or wind energy. You all seem like great fans so I would really appreciate if you would help me out knock out climate change and follow my Tour de Turtles journey!
description: Tilly is an adult hawksbill sea turtle released on July 17, 2017with a satellite transmitter. She was encountered at 10:35 pm on July 16 on Lovers Beach, Nevis. She measured 86.2 cm curved carapace (shell) length and 76.4 cm curved carapace width. Tilly is taking part in the 2017 Tour de Turtles.

name: Argus
biography: Hey there everyone, Argus here! I’m turtlely stoked to be a part of the Tour de Turtles this year! In my opinion I’m the raddest competitor in this thing! I’m not a nesting female like most of the turtles in the marathon. I was actually rescued three miles north of the 7 Mile Bridge in Marathon, FL. That’s right, Marathon! Pretty fitting for the race I’m about to begin. When I was rescued last July, I was totally not in marathon form. I was tangled in fishing line and a buoy AND covered in some gnarly tumors. Totally not tubular. My friends at the Turtle Hospital helped get me back on my flippers since I wasn’t doing so hot. I’ve had a year to recover and now I’m tumor-free and ready to head back to the sea!  I’m racing to spread the word about Poor Water Quality because clean water is crucial for sea turtles like me and my non-flippered friends. Make sure to cheer for me and spread the word about my cause! And remember, saving turtles is a Marathon, not a sprint ;)
description: Argus is a juvenile green sea turtle rescued in July, 2016, 3 miles north of the 7 mile bridge in Marathon, where she was found with a trap line and buoy entangled around her rear flipper.  Argus was taken to the Turtle Hospital for treatment. Argus’ body and eyes were covered in Fibropapilloma tumors. Argus's treatment included two tumor removal surgeries, broad spectrum antibiotics, anti-parasitic medications, vitamins, and a healthy diet of squid and greens. Argus is strong and tumor free, with a weight of 75 lbs and a shell length of 67.9 cm, and is taking part in the 2017 Tour de Turtles.

name: Cruz
project_name: Tracking Loggerheads from the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: What’s up friends? I’m Cruz! If there’s one thing I love more than cruising the big blue, it’s eating! Like check out this yummy specimen here! Wait a minute…ick! That wasn’t what I thought it was! Ugh, I am so tired of thinking I’m eating a tasty treat and it turns out to be nasty hard plastic! This isn’t just trouble for me; lots of other turtles and other marine friends have this problem too. Plastic items like water bottles, bags, and even balloons often end up as litter, which reaches our beautiful ocean waters and can hurt the tummies of my nearsighted ocean friends! The really scary part is this plastic doesn’t ever go away – it just keeps breaking down into smaller pieces. Join the Disney’s Conservation Fund in helping protect sea turtles and our other marine friends from threats like single use plastics! Choose to use paper straws (if you must use straws) like the ones we have here at Disney’s Vero Beach Resort, and select reusable bags and bottles to help keep our ocean clean! I’m making sure to hydrate now with my reusable water bottle. I’m ready to win this thing!
description: Cruz is an adult female loggerhead sea turtle to be released with a satellite transmitter on July 29, 2017 from south of the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. She measured 89.0 cm curved carapace (shell) length and 82.1 cm curved carapace width. Cruz is taking part in the 2017 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, Disney Conservation Fund.

name: Sally
project_name: Tracking Loggerheads from the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: Hey there! I’m Sally, and I am really excited to be racing in the Tour de Turtles this year to raise awareness about light pollution. I love to come up and lay my eggs on Vero Beach, especially in front of Disney’s Vero Beach Resort. It’s so relaxing and serene because there are no glaring lights, which provides a natural ambiance and makes the already difficult process of laying eggs just a little nicer. Buildings on the beach with glaring lights can make it confusing for me, but even more so for my little hatchlings! I want the best for my babies, and I don’t want them crawling into the dunes where they would get into big trouble, when they should be making their way straight to the ocean.  Thanks to Disney’s Animals, Science and Environment, and Disney’s Vero Beach Resort, many guests are being educated on the dangers of artificial lighting and how they can help. You can help by turning lights off during nesting season or by using sea turtle friendly bulbs and fixtures. And please keep flashlights off the beach at night too. Trust me, you humans have way better night vision than I do.
description: Sally is an adult female loggerhead sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter on July 29, 2017 from south of the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. She measured 86.9 cm curved carapace (shell) length and 82.7 cm curved carapace width. Sally is taking part in the 2017 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsors, Disney’s Animals, Science and Environment, and Disney’s Vero Beach Resort.

name: Odyssey
project_name: Tracking Loggerheads from the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: My name is Odyssey and I’m the most audacious loggerhead you’ll ever meet! I’ve spent the past 30 years traveling and adventuring around amazing places like the Bahamas and The Florida Keys. I recently nested on a beautiful beach in the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge and once I got word that there was an open spot in the Tour de Turtles, I just knew I had to join. My new human friends at Ripley’s Aquariums also asked for my help to raise awareness about a serious threat… Beach erosion. Now, I’m not really scared of much, but doesn’t that sound frightening? Almost half of Florida’s nesting beaches are critically eroded. Beach renourishment is the primary strategy to combat coastal erosion in Florida. While this can help, it must be carried out correctly and under strict guidelines that ensure the "new beach" is compatible for successful nesting. STC is keeping a close eye on things at home, so I think it’s about time for me to jet on outta here and spread the word!
description: An adult female loggerhead sea turtle to be released with a satellite transmitter on July 30, 2017 from the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. She measured 90.6 cm curved carapace (shell) length and 84.0 cm curved carapace width. Odyssey is taking part in the 2017 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, Ripley's Aquariums.

name: Reefie
biography: Greetings! My name is Reefie, and I come from a very sacred place – Tortuguero, Costa Rica! My green turtle friends and I love to nest at Tortuguero, but I have something scary to tell you: We were almost completely wiped out not too long ago there by poachers trying to eat us! Luckily Dr. Archie Carr saved us just in the nick of time, but poachers are still at work today! Did you know that people still consume turtle eggs for food? In some cultures, eggs are served during special occasions. I personally think humans should eat at my sponsor’s restaurant, the Greene Turtle, instead of stealing turtle eggs. If you can’t make it to a Greene Turtle restaurant, you can still help by supporting ecotourism based on turtles like me and not on consumption, keeping a safe distance away from our nests, and reporting poachers who try to steal eggs from our nests!
description: Reefie is an adult female green sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter on August 7,2017 from Tortuguero National Park in Costa Rica. She measured 109.0 cm in straight carapace (shell) length. She was named by her sponsor, The Greene Turtle Sports Bar & Grille, and took part in the 2017 Tour de Turtles. UPDATE: On the night of July 18, 2020, STC researchers encountered Reefieon the beach in Tortuguero. It was great to see her back on the nesting beach!

name: Tartle
biography: Hold on, I’m almost ready for my close-up. Okay, hello darlings! I’m Tartle. We green sea turtles naturally have the prettiest of shells, but it doesn’t hurt to have a little something extra like tarte cosmetics to help make me look THIS good while I’m working hard on laying my offspring on the beautiful beaches of Tortugero, Costa Rica. You never know who will be waiting for me upon my return. Hopefully it’s another fun turtle like me, instead of the weird gooky stuff you humans call oil. That stuff just gets all over and won’t come off! I know, I know, it’s not the end of the world if it smears on the back of my shell. It is a big deal though if my food has been contaminated! I have a figure to maintain, so all I eat is sea grass and algae. I guess you can say I’m vegan, just like my good friends at tarte. An oil spill could be a real problem if my only food source is covered in it! Plus, I don’t want my little ones swimming through that toxic mess! Please support me so my little one and I can stay safe and looking oh so fine!
description: Tartle is an adult female green sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter on August 7,2017 from Tortuguero National Park in Costa Rica. She measured 112.0 cm in straight carapace (shell) length. She was named by her sponsor, tarte, and is taking part in the 2017 Tour de Turtles.

name: Blitzen
biography: None
description: Blitzen is an adult male loggerhead sea turtle that was rescued on December 24, 2016 on Hutchinson Island, Florida. Blitzen was first noticed struggling to swim in rough surf by homeowners on Hutchinson Island who reported the turtle to Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission. Blitzen was suffering from malnutrition, dehydration, and a head injury. Blitzen was transferred to Gumbo Limbo Nature Center for his rehabilitation. After months of attentive care from our sea turtle rehabilitation staff, Blitzen is ready to return to the ocean. A satellite tag has been applied to follow Blitzen's movements once he is released. Gumbo Limbo Nature Center's staff is thrilled to be releasing another successfully rehabilitated sea turtle and we hope you'll join us to send him off.

name: Angel
biography: Well hello there! My name is Angel. I was named by my sponsor, DivinityLA. They have promised to watch over me and be my guardian angel of sorts during the Tour de Turtles. Now why would I need a guardian angel? Well during the race, I am hoping to raise awareness about a cause that is near and dear to my heart, which is the threat of poaching.  Although we sea turtles have spiritual or mythological importance in many cultures around the world, this has not prevented humans from consuming our eggs or meat. In many coastal communities, especially in Central America and Asia, sea turtles are considered a food source. During the nesting season, hunters comb the beaches at night looking for nesting females like me. In some countries, sea turtle eggs are prized as an aphrodisiac, which is just absurd. Others customarily consume sea turtle meat in observance of religious holidays, which sounds blasphemous to me! So join me throughout the Tour de Turtles as I try to put an end to the consumption of sea turtle meat and eggs! Just because I may seem nice and angelic, don’t count me out. I plan on flying through this race like the Angel that I am!
description: Angel is an adult female green sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter  from Tortuguero National Park in Costa Rica. She measured 102.8 cm in straight carapace (shell) length, and 109.0 cm in curved carapace length. She was named by her sponsor, DivinityLA, and is taking part in the 2017 Tour de Turtles.

name: Sheldon
biography: None
description: "Sheldon" is a 59.0 cm green turtle that was captured in a net at Somerset Long Bay, Bermuda, on 18 August 2017.  This was the first time that this turtle had been captured. It weighed 25.4 kilograms. The turtle was captured as part of the Bermuda Turtle Project which focuses on the study of immature green turtles in developmental habitat.

name: Kraken
biography: None
description: Kraken, the adult female loggerhead sea turtle, arrived to Gumbo Limbo's Sea Turtle Rehabilitation Facility on June 11, 2017. She was found floating in the Indian River Lagoon suffering from a severe boat propeller strike injury. Her face was lacerated and she was admitted to emergency surgery immediately upon arrival. After several months of rehabilitation, surgeries, and even Hurricane Irma, she is healed, measures 87.0 cm straight carapace length, & weighs a healthy 181 lbs! Despite missing her missing eye, she has recovered fully and been deemed ready for release by the sea turtle veterinarian.

name: Lucaya
biography: Hola! Me llamo es Lucaya! Even though I was born in Panama, I’m quite the world traveler and my name is actually Bahamian. It was given to me by my amazing sponsors at Atlantis Paradise Island. They’ve been supporting my other leatherback friends from this very beach for eightyears! I was so excited when I heard it was finally my turn to represent Team Atlantis in this year’s Tour de Turtles race. I already have more than 25 years of experience migrating under my flippers, so they knew I was the best choice to join them in raising awareness about commercial trawl fisheries. Throughout my years of traveling the globe, I have seen a lot of amazing things, and some not so amazing things… commercial trawl fisheries being one of those. Commercial trawl fisheries are big boats that drag giant nets behind them, catching all kinds of creatures. I’ve been lucky that I haven’t gotten stuck in one yet, but it would be very easy for me to get trapped in the net! To make sure other leatherbacks like me don’t get stuck in these nets, make sure you’re eating sustainably sourced fish and supporting companies and countries that use Turtle Excluder Devices on trawl boats. I plan on exploring some new territory this year, so flippers crossed I don’t run into any trawl fisheries during my travels!
description: Lucaya is an adult female leatherback sea turtle encountered nesting on May 27, 2018, on Soropta Beach, Panama. She measured 151.5 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 108.4 cm curved carapace width. Lucaya was named by her sponsor, Atlantis Resort, Paradise Island, Bahamas, and is taking part in the 2018 Tour de Turtles.

name: Certina
biography: What’s up guys? My name is Certina! I started training for the Tour de Turtles race right after I was tagged in Panama on May 28th. Since then, I’ve been stretching my flippers and perfecting my dive to take on the other competitors. Luckily I’ve been able to time my long distance swims and sprints thanks to my sponsors at Certina watches. Great name if I do say so myself! We decided to partner up with the Tour de Turtles program to help raise awareness about invasive species predation. Even though I’m super athletic, it’s not easy getting this big, beautiful body up on a beach and digging the perfect egg chamber. And after all of this work, some animals like dogs, raccoons, and boars have the NERVE to dig up MY nest! It’s time to put a stop to that here and now. Like my friends at Certina say, you can count on me! I haven’t decided what route I should take to my foraging grounds yet but I’m looking to set a new record this year by swimming the farthest in the shortest amount of time, so I’ll need everyone cheering for me!
description: Certina is an adult female leatherback sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter from Soropta Beach, Panama on May 28, 2018. She measured 156.7 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 106.2 cm in curved carapace width. She was named by her sponsor, Certina, and took part in the 2018 Tour de Turtles.

name: Dune
biography: None
description: Dune is an adult female loggerhead sea turtle released on May 22, 2018 from Gumbo Limbo Nature Center’s Sea Turtle Rehabilitation Facility.  Dune was found floating in the intracoastal unable to dive by boaters and reported to Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission on February 24, 2018. Gumbo Limbo Rehabilitation Facility treated Dune for a lung infection, related buoyancy issues, and severe emaciation. After over four months of rehabilitation, Dune has completely recovered and deemed ready for release by the sea turtle veterinarian. Dune measured 84.6 cm straight carapace length and gained over 40 lbs during her rehabilitation, weighing 176 lbs upon release!

name: Rebecca
biography: None
description: Rebecca is a juvenile green sea turtle that has been treated three times since 2016 in Gumbo Limbo’s Rehabilitation Facility for interactions with hooks and fishing line. On her most recent stranding, Rebecca’s front left flipper and neck were entangled severely in monofilament and hooks.  The wound was treated with medicinal leeches and cold laser therapy to try to prevent the flipper from being amputated. Rebecca has made a full recovery after 3 months of rehabilitation and will be released in sea grass habitat in Biscayne National Park.

name: Walter
biography: None
description: Walter is an adult, male loggerhead that stranded on June 4, 2018. He is 101.0 cm CCL (curved carapace length) long and 90.0 cm wide. He was rescued and taken to the Clinic for the Rehabilitation of Wildlife (CROW) in Sanibel, FL where he was treated for exposure to Red Tide. He is being satellite tagged as part of a study on the movement of adult male loggerheads conducted in cooperation with Mote Marine Laboratory. He was named in honor of CROW’s 50th Anniversary and their Founder, Shirley J. Walter.

name: Betsy
biography: Que tal amigos? Me llamo Betsy! My interests include swimming marathons, drinking café con leche, dancing, and eating a strictly vegetarian diet. I’ve been training hard for my next marathon so I’m spending a lot of time in the water, as most adult sea turtles do. You know what I’ve noticed recently? There are way too many longline fisheries out there! Each year, foraging and migrating sea turtles like me are accidentally captured, injured or killed by fishermen using longlines to catch tuna, swordfish, sharks and other species. A longline consists of a mainline 40 or more miles long with thousands of additional lines and hooks attached to it. What if I were to get tangled up in one of these fishing lines during the Tour de Turtles, then I wouldn’t even be able to finish the race! I’d hate to disappoint my fans and sponsors at Shark Reef Aquarium. That’s why I need your help to spread the word about the dangers of longline fisheries to your families and friends. If I win this whole thing, I’ll treat everyone to a nice dinner of some sustainable seafood!
description: Betsy is an adult green turtle released with a satellite transmitter from Guanahacabibes Natural Park, Cuba on July 4, 2018. She measured 102.0 cm in curved carapace (shell) length, 91.0 cm in curved carapace width, and deposited 112 eggs into her nest. Betsy is taking part in the 2018 Tour de Turtles and is sponsored by Shark Reef Aquarium.

name: Liberty
biography: Hello fellow patriots! My name is Liberty because I was found nesting on the 4th of July. Lucky for me, I nested in a protected national park where the water is very clean and clear, but I heard it through the grapevine that humans have been allowing chemicals and waste to run-off in other areas I might migrate through! The ocean, while it seems so vast, has apparently been a dumping ground for much of the waste produced on land for longer than I’ve even been alive. This can seriously mess with the water quality. Even if it isn’t direct pollution, harmful toxins like fertilizer and pesticides are sneakily making their way towards the ocean and can enter my food supply. I was astonished to learn this! I can’t have these chemicals in my body while I’m prepping for a marathon! I used my connections to hook up with The Turtle Hospital and STC who will help us put a stop to this madness, but we can’t do it without your support. Together, we will make sure there’s clean water, liberty, and justice for all turtles!
description: Liberty is an adult loggerhead sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter from Guanahacabibes Natural Park, Cuba on July 4, 2018. She measured 100.0 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 92.0 cm in curved carapace width. While Guanahacabibes is predominately a green turtle nesting beach, loggerheads and hawksbills do occasionally nest as well. Liberty is the first adult loggerhead satellite tracked from Cuba. She is taking part in the 2018 Tour de Turtles and is sponsored by The Turtle Hospital in Marathon, Florida Keys.

name: Colada
biography: Hey party people! My name is Colada and word on the island is that I’m the favorite beverage, er, turtle in this race! I’ve had some other hawksbill friends participate in the Tour de Turtles the past 10 years and it totally sounds like my kind of event. Island hopping, hanging out on the beach, swimming with friends…. Count me in! I’ll also be spreading the word about a serious threat to beautiful hawksbills like me—illegal shell trade. Unfortunately, instead of just admiring me, some humans want to take my gorgeous shell and make it into art of their own, like jewelry, hair accessories and other trinkets. What am I supposed to do without my shell, be a naked turtle?! I sure hope you agree and join me and my friends at the Sea Turtle Conservancy in spreading the word about the illegal shell trade. Remember, you can look but you can’t touch!
description: Colada is an adult hawksbill sea turtle released on July 15, 2018 with a satellite transmitter. She was encountered nesting on July 14 on Cades Bay Beach, Nevis. She measured 82.7 cm curved carapace (shell) length and 77.9 cm curved carapace width. Colada is taking part in the 2018 Tour de Turtles.

name: Kali
biography: Hello there! My name is Kali, which is short for “Kalinago,” and I’m named after the Island Caribs who inhabited my homeland of Nevis. Even though I prefer the slow-paced, island lifestyle most of the time, I agreed to participate in this year’s Tour de Turtles to help out my sponsors at the Four Seasons Nevis. It might all seem like a tropical paradise now, but the reason I was selected is to raise awareness about the dangers of climate change, a major threat to our beautiful beaches. Because of climate change, sea levels are rising, resulting in the disappearance of many nesting beaches. To battle this problem, humans can use energy-saving methods of transportation, plant vegetation along beaches to provide better nesting habitat, and use more solar or wind energy. I plan to swim throughout the Caribbean to let everyone know about climate change and how they can help. I’ll try my best not to get stuck on island time, but I can’t make any promises!
description: Kali is an adult hawksbill sea turtle released on July 16, 2018 with a satellite transmitter. Kali is short for “Kalinago” which was an indigenous group of people in the Lesser Antilles. She was encountered nesting on July 15 on Lover's Beach, Nevis. She measured 85.0 cm curved carapace (shell) length and 79.0 vc curved carapace width. Kali is taking part in the 2018 Tour de Turtles.

name: Coco
biography: Hey there everyone, Coco here! I’m turtlely stoked to be a part of Tour de Turtles this year! In my opinion I’m the raddest competitor in this thing! I’m not a nesting female like most of the turtles in the marathon, I’m actually an adult male! It is a rare opportunity to track an adult male sea turtle like me because male turtles do not normally return to land after we hatch out as babies. When I was rescued back in February, I was totally not in marathon form. I was very thin and edematous, covered in barnacles and algae.  X-rays revealed a severe intestinal impaction and pneumonia. Totally not tubular. My friends at The Turtle Hospital helped me get back on my flippers by giving me IV nutrition, broad spectrum antibiotics, lactulose, fluids and eventually, when I got my appetite back, a healthy diet of fish and squid. I passed almost 4 pounds of shells and gained 25 pounds. Now I’m back stronger than ever, weighing in at a healthy 215 lbs! I’m racing to spread the word about Poor Water Quality because clean water is crucial for sea turtles like me and my non-flippered friends. Make sure to cheer for me and spread the word to your friends!
description: A 215 pound adult male loggerhead sea turtle was rescued 9 miles offshore of Marathon in the Florida Bay and taken to the Turtle Hospital on February 27th, 2018. Coco was very thin and covered in barnacles and algae. X-rays revealed a severe intestinal impaction and pneumonia. Treatment included IV nutrition, broad spectrum antibiotics, lactulose, fluids and eventually, when he began eating, a healthy diet of fish and squid. It is a rare opportunity to track an adult male sea turtle. Coco is healthy and ready to go back to sea! We are very interested to see where this big boy goes!

name: Little Money
biography: Hi guys! I’m Little Money! Or “Not So Little Money” as my friends at The Turtle Hospital called me. It’s probably because I weigh a whopping 365 pounds! Although I’m an adult female turtle like most of my competitors, I was not nesting when I was found. I was actually found by a boater beached on Money Key back in June. It took two Turtle Hospital staff and three FWC officers on two boats to rescue me. I was treated at the Turtle Hospital for gastrointestinal issues and received broad spectrum antibiotics, vitamins, fluids and a healthy diet. Now that I’m healthy and swimming strong, I’m ready to return to my ocean home! I’m swimming to help raise awareness about boat strikes and safe boating practices. A lot of my flippered friends back at the hospital were actually boat strike victims, so it’s a cause close to my heart. My buddy Coco and I are the only rehabilitated turtles participating in the race, which is pretty neat! And who knows, since I’m a mature female, maybe I’ll come back to shore to nest this season? Only time will tell!
description: A 365 pound adult female green sea turtle was found by a boater beached on Money Key on June 20th. She was recused by the Turtle Hospital and FWC and was treated at the Turtle Hospital for gastrointestinal issues. Little Money received broad spectrum antibiotics, vitamins, fluids and a healthy diet.  She is swimming strong, healthy and ready to return to her ocean home! Little Money is a mature female...there is a chance she may come back to shore to nest this season!

name: Trixie
project_name: Tracking Loggerheads from the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: Hiya! I’m Trixie! I’ve been working really hard to prepare for the race this year in order to raise awareness about light pollution. Vero Beach is my favorite spot to nest for many reasons. One of those is because Disney’s Vero Beach Resort installed sea turtle-friendly lighting for me! But many beachfront hotels and condos still have bright, white lights. I have enough trouble seeing as it is, I don’t need pesky bright lights confusing me! Bright beachfront lighting can also draw little hatchlings inland and away from the ocean, which is very dangerous. This is some scary stuff so we’ve got to work together to make beaches safe for turtles. Make sure to turn off unnecessary lights visible on nesting beaches or use sea turtle-friendly fixtures to help.My game plan is to navigate my way down to the Caribbean and educate everyone along the way about the dangers of light pollution. I might not be the most graceful turtle in the bunch, but I’m ready to pull off a few “tricks” of my own!
description: Trixie is an adult female loggerhead sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter on July 28, 2018 from south of the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. She measured 101.1 cm curved carapace (shell) length, curved carapace width is 70.8 cm, and weighed an estimated 240 lbs. She is taking part in the 2018 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsors, Disney Parks Blog.

name: Mrs Potato Head
project_name: Tracking Loggerheads from the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: Hi, humans! As you probably already noticed, I am Mrs. Potato Head, or MPH for short. I’ve spent the past 20 years traveling around to lovely places like the Bahamas and The Florida Keys. I recently nested on a beautiful beach right in front of Disney’s Vero Beach Resort and was just too tickled at the idea of joining the Tour de Turtles! Some say I have a flair for the dramatic, but really I just want to make sure everyone knows how important my cause is. Plastic debris is a ginormous threat to marine life, especially for sea turtles and marine mammals. Items like plastic water bottles, bags, and balloons can easily make their way into the ocean, where they break down into small pieces. Accidentally eating this plastic has caused the deaths of over 100 million of my marine animal friends. I certainly can’t keep all these bad items from entering the ocean by myself! I need your help! Take reusable grocery bags to the store, never release balloons, and always pick up litter. You can also follow me on my journey and help me spread the word! I know my friends at Disney will have my back, er, shell!
description: Mrs Potato Head is an adult female loggerhead sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter on July 28, 2018 from south of the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. She measured 108.8 cm curved carapace (shell) length, 92.2 curved carapace width, and weighed 294 lbs. She is taking part in the 2018 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsors, Disney Parks Blog.

name: Turtlette
project_name: Tracking Loggerheads from the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: Hold on, I’m almost ready for my close-up... Okay, hello lovelies! I’m Turtlette. My sponsors at tarte cosmetics tell me that I’m the prettiest little loggerhead they’ve ever seen! I may be on the smaller side but what I lack in size I make up for in personality! I’ve been trying to bulk up a little just for the Tour de Turtles marathon by eating a lot of crabs, squid and lobster, even though my friends at tarte thinks I should be vegan like them. I mean, who do they think I am, a green turtle?! Anyways, I’ve primped and powdered my shell and can’t wait to show everyone how great I look when I make my Tour de Turtles debut. Even though everyone will probably be busy admiring my beauty, I hope they also take the time to learn about the threat of oils spills and marine pollution during my migration. I only use all-natural products on my shell, so I definitely don’t want to swim through any water that’s polluted with chemicals from fertilizers or factories. I’m so excited for you to help me on this journey!
description: Turtlette is an adult female loggerhead sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter on July 29, 2018 from the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. She measured 87.2 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and 84.1 cm curved carapace width. She was named by her sponsor, tarte, and is taking part in the 2018 Tour de Turtles.

name: Bion
project_name: Tracking Loggerheads from the Archie Carr Refuge
biography: Hey everyone, I’m Bion! My sponsors at Ripley’s Aquariums allowed me to participate in the Tour de Turtles race this year, and I’m so excited to stretch out my flippers and win this thing! I am swimming to raise awareness about the threat of beach erosion. Believe It Or Not, 80 to 90 percent of America’s sandy coastlines have been eroding for decades, according to the Environmental Protection Agency. This is bad news for sea turtles, because the only place we can lay our eggs is on sandy beaches, so we all need to work together to make sure I can keep nesting on Florida’s beaches well into the future. Because sea level rise is contributing to beach erosion, you can help by limiting emissions where you can, such as biking to work or carpooling, and electing leaders who will address climate change. You can also plant native dune vegetation on beaches, promote coastal construction set-back policies and not build structures on the beach.
description: An adult female loggerhead sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter on July 29, 2018 from the Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, Florida. She measured 102.7 cm curved carapace (shell) length and 90.6 cm curved carapace width. Bion (Believe It Or Not) is taking part in the 2018 Tour de Turtles and was named by her sponsor, Ripley's Aquariums.

name: Vida
biography: Hola! Me llamo es Vida. Here in Costa Rica, we say “Pura Vida,” which means “Pure Life.” It has been a staple in our vocabulary for more than 50 years, and it allows us to stay optimistic, happy, and full of life, despite all the negative circumstances around us, according to my sponsor, Pura Vida Bracelets! It’s easy being a happy Costa Rican green turtle, but there definitely are some negative circumstances we have to deal with, like the possibility of being killed for our meat. Some ways to stop this scary practice are to support government-imposed limits on consumption, patrol beaches at night for poachers, educate the public about how important we are to the ecosystem, and create eco-tourism programs like the Sea Turtle Conservancy has in Tortuguero, where I’m from! Thousands of visitors come to Tortuguero every year to witness sea turtles nest, and the economy in Tortuguero thrives off of it! By moving from the consumptive use of sea turtles to eco-tourism, STC has found that green turtles are worth much more alive than dead. It gives a whole new meaning to the phrase Pura Vida!
description: Vida is an adult female green sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter on August 6, 2018 from Tortuguero National Park in Costa Rica. She measured 115.0 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and was named by her sponsor, Pura Vida Bracelets. She is taking part in the 2018 Tour de Turtles.

name: Crush (Cordelia)
biography: Greetings! My name is Cordelia, and I come from a very sacred place – Tortuguero, Costa Rica! My green turtle friends and I love to nest at Tortuguero, but I have something scary to tell you: We were almost completely wiped out not too long ago there by poachers trying to eat us! Luckily Dr. Archie Carr saved us just in the nick of time, but poachers are still at work today! Did you know that people still consume turtle eggs for food? In some cultures, eggs are served during special occasions. I personally think humans should eat at my sponsor’s restaurant, the Greene Turtle, instead of stealing turtle eggs. If you can’t make it to a Greene Turtle restaurant, you can still help by supporting ecotourism based on turtles like me and not on consumption, keeping a safe distance away from our nests, and reporting poachers who try to steal eggs from our nests!
description: Crush (aka Cordelia) is an adult female green sea turtle released with a satellite transmitter on August 5, 2018 from Tortuguero National Park in Costa Rica. She measured 110.0 cm in curved carapace (shell) length and was named by her sponsor, Greene Turtle Sports Bar & Grill. She is taking part in the 2018 Tour de Turtles.

name: Stella
biography: Hi friends! My name is Stella, which is short for “Constellation.” The folks over at the Sea Turtle Conservancy thought I looked like I had stars and constellations on the back of my shell when they saw me!
